thread 'main' panicked at src/main.rs:5:10:
hello.txt should be included in this project: Os { code: 2, kind: NotFound, message: "No such file or directory" }

í”„ë¡œë•ì…˜ í’ˆì§ˆì˜ ì½”ë“œì—ì„œ ëŒ€ë¶€ë¶„ì˜ ëŸ¬ìŠ¤íŠ¸ ì‚¬ìš©ìë“¤ì€ unwrapë³´ë‹¤ëŠ” expectë¥¼ ì„ íƒí•˜ê³ , ì™œ ì‘ì—…ì´ í•­ìƒ ì„±ê³µí•  ê²ƒìœ¼ë¡œ ì˜ˆìƒë˜ëŠ”ì§€ì— ëŒ€í•œ ë” ë§ì€ ë¬¸ë§¥ì„ ì œê³µí•©ë‹ˆë‹¤. ê·¸ë ‡ê²Œ í•˜ë©´ ë§Œì•½ ê°€ì •ì´ í‹€ë ¸ìŒì´ ë°í˜€ì¡Œì„ ë•Œ, ë””ë²„ê¹…ì— ì‚¬ìš©í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆëŠ” ë” ë§ì€ ì •ë³´ë¥¼ ê°–ê²Œ ë©ë‹ˆë‹¤.

ì—ëŸ¬ ì „íŒŒí•˜ê¸°

When a functionâ€™s implementation calls something that might fail, instead of handling the error within the function itself, you can return the error to the calling code so that it can decide what to do. This is known as propagating the error and gives more control to the calling code, where there might be more information or logic that dictates how the error should be handled than what you have available in the context of your code.

ì˜ˆë¥¼ ë“¤ì–´, ëª©ë¡ 9-6ì€ íŒŒì¼ì—ì„œ ì‚¬ìš©ì ì´ë¦„ì„ ì½ëŠ” í•¨ìˆ˜ë¥¼ ë³´ì—¬ì¤ë‹ˆë‹¤. íŒŒì¼ì´ ì¡´ì¬í•˜ì§€ ì•Šê±°ë‚˜ ì½ì„ ìˆ˜ ì—†ëŠ” ê²½ìš°, ì´ í•¨ìˆ˜ëŠ” í•´ë‹¹ ì—ëŸ¬ë¥¼ í•¨ìˆ˜ë¥¼ í˜¸ì¶œí•œ ì½”ë“œì— ë°˜í™˜í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤.

#![allow(unused)]
fn main() {
use std::fs::File;
use std::io::{self, Read};

fn read_username_from_file() -> Result<String, io::Error> {
    let username_file_result = File::open("hello.txt");

    let mut username_file = match username_file_result {
        Ok(file) => file,
        Err(e) => return Err(e),
    };

    let mut username = String::new();

    match username_file.read_to_string(&mut username) {
        Ok(_) => Ok(username),
        Err(e) => Err(e),
    }
}
}

ì´ í•¨ìˆ˜ëŠ” í›¨ì”¬ ë” ì§§ì€ ë°©ì‹ìœ¼ë¡œ ì‘ì„±ë  ìˆ˜ ìˆì§€ë§Œ, ì—ëŸ¬ ì²˜ë¦¬ë¥¼ íƒêµ¬í•˜ê¸° ìœ„í•´ ë§ì€ ë¶€ë¶„ì„ ìˆ˜ë™ìœ¼ë¡œ ìˆ˜í–‰í•˜ëŠ” ê²ƒìœ¼ë¡œ ì‹œì‘í•  ê²ƒì…ë‹ˆë‹¤; ë§ˆì§€ë§‰ì—ëŠ” ë” ì§§ì€ ë°©ë²•ì„ ë³´ì—¬ì¤„ ê²ƒì…ë‹ˆë‹¤. ë¨¼ì € í•¨ìˆ˜ì˜ ë°˜í™˜ íƒ€ì…ì„ ì‚´í´ë´…ì‹œë‹¤: Result<String, io::Error>. ì´ëŠ” í•¨ìˆ˜ê°€ Result<T, E> íƒ€ì…ì˜ ê°’ì„ ë°˜í™˜í•˜ê³  ìˆìŒì„ ì˜ë¯¸í•˜ë©°, ì—¬ê¸°ì„œ ì œë„¤ë¦­ ë§¤ê°œë³€ìˆ˜ TëŠ” êµ¬ì²´ì ì¸ íƒ€ì… Stringìœ¼ë¡œ ì±„ì›Œì¡Œê³  ì œë„¤ë¦­ íƒ€ì… EëŠ” êµ¬ì²´ì ì¸ íƒ€ì… io::Errorë¡œ ì±„ì›Œì¡ŒìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤.

ì´ í•¨ìˆ˜ê°€ ì•„ë¬´ ë¬¸ì œ ì—†ì´ ì„±ê³µí•˜ë©´, ì´ í•¨ìˆ˜ë¥¼ í˜¸ì¶œí•˜ëŠ” ì½”ë“œëŠ” Ok ê°’ì„ ë°›ê²Œ ë˜ëŠ”ë°, ì—¬ê¸°ì—ëŠ” ì´ í•¨ìˆ˜ê°€ íŒŒì¼ì—ì„œ ì½ì€ usernameì¸ Stringì´ ë“¤ì–´ ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤. ì´ í•¨ìˆ˜ê°€ ë¬¸ì œë¥¼ ê²ªê²Œ ë˜ë©´, í˜¸ì¶œí•˜ëŠ” ì½”ë“œëŠ” Err ê°’ì„ ë°›ê²Œ ë˜ëŠ”ë°, ì—¬ê¸°ì—ëŠ” ë¬¸ì œê°€ ë¬´ì—‡ì´ì—ˆëŠ”ì§€ì— ëŒ€í•œ ë” ë§ì€ ì •ë³´ë¥¼ ë‹´ê³  ìˆëŠ” io::Errorì˜ ì¸ìŠ¤í„´ìŠ¤ê°€ ë“¤ì–´ ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤. ìš°ë¦¬ëŠ” ì´ í•¨ìˆ˜ì˜ ë°˜í™˜ íƒ€ì…ìœ¼ë¡œ io::Errorë¥¼ ì„ íƒí–ˆëŠ”ë°, ì™œëƒí•˜ë©´ ì´ í•¨ìˆ˜ ë³¸ë¬¸ì—ì„œ í˜¸ì¶œí•˜ëŠ” ì‹¤íŒ¨í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆëŠ” ë‘ ì‘ì—…, ì¦‰ File::open í•¨ìˆ˜ì™€ read_to_string ë©”ì„œë“œ ëª¨ë‘ì—ì„œ ë°˜í™˜ë˜ëŠ” ì—ëŸ¬ ê°’ì˜ íƒ€ì…ì´ ë°”ë¡œ ê·¸ê²ƒì´ê¸° ë•Œë¬¸ì…ë‹ˆë‹¤.

The body of the function starts by calling the File::open function. Then, we handle the Result value with a match similar to the match in Listing 9-4. If File::open succeeds, the file handle in the pattern variable file becomes the value in the mutable variable username_file and the function continues. In the Err case, instead of calling panic!, we use the return keyword to return early out of the function entirely and pass the error value from File::open, now in the pattern variable e, back to the calling code as this functionâ€™s error value.

So, if we have a file handle in username_file, the function then creates a new String in variable username and calls the read_to_string method on the file handle in username_file to read the contents of the file into username. The read_to_string method also returns a Result because it might fail, even though File::open succeeded. So, we need another match to handle that Result: If read_to_string succeeds, then our function has succeeded, and we return the username from the file thatâ€™s now in username wrapped in an Ok. If read_to_string fails, we return the error value in the same way that we returned the error value in the match that handled the return value of File::open. However, we donâ€™t need to explicitly say return, because this is the last expression in the function.

ì´ ì½”ë“œë¥¼ í˜¸ì¶œí•˜ëŠ” ì½”ë“œëŠ” ì‚¬ìš©ì ì´ë¦„ì„ í¬í•¨í•˜ëŠ” Ok ê°’ì´ë‚˜ io::Errorë¥¼ í¬í•¨í•˜ëŠ” Err ê°’ ì¤‘ í•˜ë‚˜ë¥¼ ë°›ì•„ì„œ ì²˜ë¦¬í•˜ê²Œ ë©ë‹ˆë‹¤. ì´ ê°’ë“¤ë¡œ ë¬´ì—‡ì„ í• ì§€ëŠ” í˜¸ì¶œí•˜ëŠ” ì½”ë“œê°€ ê²°ì •í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤. í˜¸ì¶œí•˜ëŠ” ì½”ë“œê°€ Err ê°’ì„ ë°›ìœ¼ë©´ panic!ì„ í˜¸ì¶œí•˜ì—¬ í”„ë¡œê·¸ë¨ì„ ì¤‘ë‹¨ì‹œí‚¤ê±°ë‚˜, ê¸°ë³¸ ì‚¬ìš©ì ì´ë¦„ì„ ì‚¬ìš©í•˜ê±°ë‚˜, íŒŒì¼ì´ ì•„ë‹Œ ë‹¤ë¥¸ ê³³ì—ì„œ ì‚¬ìš©ì ì´ë¦„ì„ ì¡°íšŒí•˜ëŠ” ë“±ì˜ ì‘ì—…ì„ í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤. í˜¸ì¶œí•˜ëŠ” ì½”ë“œê°€ ì‹¤ì œë¡œ ë¬´ì—‡ì„ í•˜ë ¤ëŠ”ì§€ì— ëŒ€í•œ ì •ë³´ê°€ ì¶©ë¶„í•˜ì§€ ì•Šìœ¼ë¯€ë¡œ, ìš°ë¦¬ëŠ” ëª¨ë“  ì„±ê³µ ë˜ëŠ” ì—ëŸ¬ ì •ë³´ë¥¼ ìœ„ë¡œ ì „íŒŒí•˜ì—¬ ì ì ˆí•˜ê²Œ ì²˜ë¦¬í•˜ë„ë¡ í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤.

ì—ëŸ¬ë¥¼ ì „íŒŒí•˜ëŠ” ì´ íŒ¨í„´ì€ ëŸ¬ìŠ¤íŠ¸ì—ì„œ ë§¤ìš° í”í•˜ë¯€ë¡œ, ëŸ¬ìŠ¤íŠ¸ëŠ” ì´ë¥¼ ë” ì‰½ê²Œ ë§Œë“¤ê¸° ìœ„í•´ ë¬¼ìŒí‘œ ì—°ì‚°ì ?ë¥¼ ì œê³µí•©ë‹ˆë‹¤.

The ? Operator Shortcut

ëª©ë¡ 9-7ì€ ëª©ë¡ 9-6ê³¼ ë™ì¼í•œ ê¸°ëŠ¥ì„ ê°€ì§€ì§€ë§Œ ? ì—°ì‚°ìë¥¼ ì‚¬ìš©í•˜ëŠ” read_username_from_fileì˜ êµ¬í˜„ì„ ë³´ì—¬ì¤ë‹ˆë‹¤.

#![allow(unused)]
fn main() {
use std::fs::File;
use std::io::{self, Read};

fn read_username_from_file() -> Result<String, io::Error> {
    let mut username_file = File::open("hello.txt")?;
    let mut username = String::new();
    username_file.read_to_string(&mut username)?;
    Ok(username)
}
}

The ? placed after a Result value is defined to work in almost the same way as the match expressions that we defined to handle the Result values in Listing 9-6. If the value of the Result is an Ok, the value inside the Ok will get returned from this expression, and the program will continue. If the value is an Err, the Err will be returned from the whole function as if we had used the return keyword so that the error value gets propagated to the calling code.

There is a difference between what the match expression from Listing 9-6 does and what the ? operator does: Error values that have the ? operator called on them go through the from function, defined in the From trait in the standard library, which is used to convert values from one type into another. When the ? operator calls the from function, the error type received is converted into the error type defined in the return type of the current function. This is useful when a function returns one error type to represent all the ways a function might fail, even if parts might fail for many different reasons.

ì˜ˆë¥¼ ë“¤ì–´, ëª©ë¡ 9-7ì˜ read_username_from_file í•¨ìˆ˜ë¥¼ ë³€ê²½í•˜ì—¬ ìš°ë¦¬ê°€ ì •ì˜í•œ OurErrorë¼ëŠ” ì‚¬ìš©ì ì •ì˜ ì—ëŸ¬ íƒ€ì…ì„ ë°˜í™˜í•˜ê²Œ í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤. ë§Œì•½ io::Errorë¡œë¶€í„° OurErrorì˜ ì¸ìŠ¤í„´ìŠ¤ë¥¼ ìƒì„±í•˜ëŠ” impl From<io::Error> for OurErrorë„ ì •ì˜í•œë‹¤ë©´, read_username_from_file ë³¸ë¬¸ì˜ ? ì—°ì‚°ì í˜¸ì¶œì€ fromì„ í˜¸ì¶œí•˜ì—¬ í•¨ìˆ˜ì— ë” ì´ìƒ ì½”ë“œë¥¼ ì¶”ê°€í•  í•„ìš” ì—†ì´ ì—ëŸ¬ íƒ€ì…ì„ ë³€í™˜í•  ê²ƒì…ë‹ˆë‹¤.

ëª©ë¡ 9-7ì˜ ë¬¸ë§¥ì—ì„œ File::open í˜¸ì¶œ ëì— ìˆëŠ” ?ëŠ” Ok ë‚´ë¶€ì˜ ê°’ì„ username_file ë³€ìˆ˜ì— ë°˜í™˜í•  ê²ƒì…ë‹ˆë‹¤. ì—ëŸ¬ê°€ ë°œìƒí•˜ë©´ ? ì—°ì‚°ìëŠ” ì „ì²´ í•¨ìˆ˜ì—ì„œ ì¼ì° ë°˜í™˜í•˜ê³  í˜¸ì¶œí•˜ëŠ” ì½”ë“œì— Err ê°’ì„ ì¤„ ê²ƒì…ë‹ˆë‹¤. read_to_string í˜¸ì¶œ ëì— ìˆëŠ” ?ì—ë„ ë™ì¼í•œ ë‚´ìš©ì´ ì ìš©ë©ë‹ˆë‹¤.

? ì—°ì‚°ìëŠ” ë§ì€ ìƒìš©êµ¬(boilerplate)ë¥¼ ì œê±°í•˜ê³  ì´ í•¨ìˆ˜ì˜ êµ¬í˜„ì„ ë” ê°„ë‹¨í•˜ê²Œ ë§Œë“­ë‹ˆë‹¤. ëª©ë¡ 9-8ì— ë‚˜ì™€ ìˆë“¯ì´ ? ë°”ë¡œ ë’¤ì— ë©”ì„œë“œ í˜¸ì¶œì„ ì—°ê²°í•˜ì—¬ ì´ ì½”ë“œë¥¼ ë” ì¤„ì¼ ìˆ˜ë„ ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤.

#![allow(unused)]
fn main() {
use std::fs::File;
use std::io::{self, Read};

fn read_username_from_file() -> Result<String, io::Error> {
    let mut username = String::new();

    File::open("hello.txt")?.read_to_string(&mut username)?;

    Ok(username)
}
}

File::open("hello.txt")?ì˜ ê²°ê³¼ì— read_to_string í˜¸ì¶œì„ ì§ì ‘ ì—°ê²°í–ˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤. read_to_string í˜¸ì¶œ ëì— ì—¬ì „íˆ ?ê°€ ìˆê³ , File::openê³¼ read_to_stringì´ ëª¨ë‘ ì„±ê³µí–ˆì„ ë•Œ ì—ëŸ¬ë¥¼ ë°˜í™˜í•˜ëŠ” ëŒ€ì‹  usernameì„ í¬í•¨í•˜ëŠ” Ok ê°’ì„ ì—¬ì „íˆ ë°˜í™˜í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤. ê¸°ëŠ¥ì€ ëª©ë¡ 9-6 ë° ëª©ë¡ 9-7ê³¼ ë™ì¼í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤. ë‹¨ì§€ ì‘ì„±í•˜ëŠ” ë°©ì‹ì´ ë‹¤ë¥´ê³  ë” ì¸ì²´ê³µí•™ì ì¼ ë¿ì…ë‹ˆë‹¤.

ëª©ë¡ 9-9ëŠ” fs::read_to_stringì„ ì‚¬ìš©í•˜ì—¬ ì´ë¥¼ ë” ì§§ê²Œ ë§Œë“œëŠ” ë°©ë²•ì„ ë³´ì—¬ì¤ë‹ˆë‹¤.

#![allow(unused)]
fn main() {
use std::fs;
use std::io;

fn read_username_from_file() -> Result<String, io::Error> {
    fs::read_to_string("hello.txt")
}
}

íŒŒì¼ì„ ë¬¸ìì—´ë¡œ ì½ëŠ” ê²ƒì€ ê½¤ ì¼ë°˜ì ì¸ ì‘ì—…ì´ë¯€ë¡œ, í‘œì¤€ ë¼ì´ë¸ŒëŸ¬ë¦¬ëŠ” íŒŒì¼ì„ ì—´ê³ , ìƒˆ Stringì„ ìƒì„±í•˜ê³ , íŒŒì¼ ë‚´ìš©ì„ ì½ê³ , ë‚´ìš©ì„ ê·¸ Stringì— ë„£ê³ , ë°˜í™˜í•˜ëŠ” í¸ë¦¬í•œ fs::read_to_string í•¨ìˆ˜ë¥¼ ì œê³µí•©ë‹ˆë‹¤. ë¬¼ë¡  fs::read_to_stringì„ ì‚¬ìš©í•˜ë©´ ëª¨ë“  ì—ëŸ¬ ì²˜ë¦¬ë¥¼ ì„¤ëª…í•  ê¸°íšŒê°€ ì—†ì—ˆê¸° ë•Œë¬¸ì— ë¨¼ì € ë” ê¸´ ë°©ë²•ìœ¼ë¡œ í–ˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤.

Where to Use the ? Operator

? ì—°ì‚°ìëŠ” ?ê°€ ì‚¬ìš©ëœ ê°’ê³¼ í˜¸í™˜ë˜ëŠ” ë°˜í™˜ íƒ€ì…ì„ ê°€ì§„ í•¨ìˆ˜ì—ì„œë§Œ ì‚¬ìš©í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤. ì´ëŠ” ? ì—°ì‚°ìê°€ ëª©ë¡ 9-6ì—ì„œ ì •ì˜í•œ match í‘œí˜„ì‹ê³¼ ê°™ì€ ë°©ì‹ìœ¼ë¡œ í•¨ìˆ˜ì—ì„œ ê°’ì„ ì¼ì° ë°˜í™˜í•˜ë„ë¡ ì •ì˜ë˜ì–´ ìˆê¸° ë•Œë¬¸ì…ë‹ˆë‹¤. ëª©ë¡ 9-6ì—ì„œ matchëŠ” Result ê°’ì„ ì‚¬ìš©í•˜ê³  ìˆì—ˆê³ , ì¡°ê¸° ë°˜í™˜ ê°ˆë˜ëŠ” Err(e) ê°’ì„ ë°˜í™˜í–ˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤. í•¨ìˆ˜ì˜ ë°˜í™˜ íƒ€ì…ì€ ì´ returnê³¼ í˜¸í™˜ë˜ë„ë¡ Resultì—¬ì•¼ í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤.

ëª©ë¡ 9-10ì—ì„œ, ?ë¥¼ ì‚¬ìš©í•˜ëŠ” ê°’ì˜ íƒ€ì…ê³¼ í˜¸í™˜ë˜ì§€ ì•ŠëŠ” ë°˜í™˜ íƒ€ì…ì„ ê°€ì§„ main í•¨ìˆ˜ì—ì„œ ? ì—°ì‚°ìë¥¼ ì‚¬ìš©í•˜ë©´ ì–´ë–¤ ì—ëŸ¬ê°€ ë°œìƒí•˜ëŠ”ì§€ ì‚´í´ë´…ì‹œë‹¤.

use std::fs::File;

fn main() {
    let greeting_file = File::open("hello.txt")?;
}

ì´ ì½”ë“œëŠ” íŒŒì¼ì„ ì—¬ëŠ”ë°, ì‹¤íŒ¨í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤. ? ì—°ì‚°ìëŠ” File::openì´ ë°˜í™˜í•œ Result ê°’ì„ ë”°ë¥´ì§€ë§Œ, ì´ main í•¨ìˆ˜ëŠ” Resultê°€ ì•„ë‹Œ () ë°˜í™˜ íƒ€ì…ì„ ê°€ì§‘ë‹ˆë‹¤. ì´ ì½”ë“œë¥¼ ì»´íŒŒì¼í•˜ë©´ ë‹¤ìŒê³¼ ê°™ì€ ì—ëŸ¬ ë©”ì‹œì§€ë¥¼ ì–»ìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤:

$ cargo run
   Compiling error-handling v0.1.0 (file:///projects/error-handling)
error[E0277]: the `?` operator can only be used in a function that returns `Result` or `Option` (or another type that implements `FromResidual`)
 --> src/main.rs:4:48
  |
3 | fn main() {
  | --------- this function should return `Result` or `Option` to accept `?`
4 |     let greeting_file = File::open("hello.txt")?;
  |                                                ^ cannot use the `?` operator in a function that returns `()`
  |
help: consider adding return type
  |
3 ~ fn main() -> Result<(), Box<dyn std::error::Error>> {
4 |     let greeting_file = File::open("hello.txt")?;
5 +     Ok(())
  |

For more information about this error, try `rustc --explain E0277`.
error: could not compile `error-handling` (bin "error-handling") due to 1 previous error

ì´ ì—ëŸ¬ëŠ” ìš°ë¦¬ê°€ Result, Option, ë˜ëŠ” FromResidualì„ êµ¬í˜„í•˜ëŠ” ë‹¤ë¥¸ íƒ€ì…ì„ ë°˜í™˜í•˜ëŠ” í•¨ìˆ˜ì—ì„œë§Œ ? ì—°ì‚°ìë¥¼ ì‚¬ìš©í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆë‹¤ê³  ì§€ì í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤.

ì—ëŸ¬ë¥¼ ìˆ˜ì •í•˜ë ¤ë©´ ë‘ ê°€ì§€ ì„ íƒì§€ê°€ ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤. í•˜ë‚˜ëŠ” í•¨ìˆ˜ê°€ ì´ë¥¼ ë§‰ëŠ” ì œí•œì´ ì—†ëŠ” í•œ, ? ì—°ì‚°ìë¥¼ ì‚¬ìš©í•˜ëŠ” ê°’ê³¼ í˜¸í™˜ë˜ë„ë¡ í•¨ìˆ˜ì˜ ë°˜í™˜ íƒ€ì…ì„ ë³€ê²½í•˜ëŠ” ê²ƒì…ë‹ˆë‹¤. ë‹¤ë¥¸ í•˜ë‚˜ëŠ” matchë‚˜ Result<T, E> ë©”ì„œë“œ ì¤‘ í•˜ë‚˜ë¥¼ ì‚¬ìš©í•˜ì—¬ ì ì ˆí•œ ë°©ì‹ìœ¼ë¡œ Result<T, E>ë¥¼ ì²˜ë¦¬í•˜ëŠ” ê²ƒì…ë‹ˆë‹¤.

The error message also mentioned that ? can be used with Option<T> values as well. As with using ? on Result, you can only use ? on Option in a function that returns an Option. The behavior of the ? operator when called on an Option<T> is similar to its behavior when called on a Result<T, E>: If the value is None, the None will be returned early from the function at that point. If the value is Some, the value inside the Some is the resultant value of the expression, and the function continues. Listing 9-11 has an example of a function that finds the last character of the first line in the given text.

fn last_char_of_first_line(text: &str) -> Option<char> {
    text.lines().next()?.chars().last()
}

fn main() {
    assert_eq!(
        last_char_of_first_line("Hello, world\nì˜¤ëŠ˜ ê¸°ë¶„ ì–´ë– ì„¸ìš”?"),
        Some(ì—ëŸ¬ê°€ ë°œìƒí•˜ë©´, `?` ì—°ì‚°ìëŠ” `from` í•¨ìˆ˜ë¥¼ ì‚¬ìš©í•˜ì—¬ ë°›ì€ ì—ëŸ¬ íƒ€ì…ì„ í˜„ì¬ í•¨ìˆ˜ì˜ ë°˜í™˜ íƒ€ì…ì— ì •ì˜ëœ ì—ëŸ¬ íƒ€ì…ìœ¼ë¡œ ë³€í™˜í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤. ì´ëŠ” í•¨ìˆ˜ê°€ ì—¬ëŸ¬ ë¶€ë¶„ì—ì„œ ë‹¤ë¥¸ ì´ìœ ë¡œ ì‹¤íŒ¨í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆë”ë¼ë„ ëª¨ë“  ì‹¤íŒ¨ ì´ìœ ë¥¼ ë‚˜íƒ€ë‚´ëŠ” í•˜ë‚˜ì˜ ì—ëŸ¬ íƒ€ì…ì„ ë°˜í™˜í•  ë•Œ ìœ ìš©í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤.)
    );

    assert_eq!(last_char_of_first_line(""), None);
    assert_eq!(last_char_of_first_line("\nhi"), None);
}

ì´ í•¨ìˆ˜ëŠ” Option<char>ë¥¼ ë°˜í™˜í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤. ë¬¸ìê°€ ìˆì„ ìˆ˜ë„ ìˆì§€ë§Œ ì—†ì„ ìˆ˜ë„ ìˆê¸° ë•Œë¬¸ì…ë‹ˆë‹¤. ì´ ì½”ë“œëŠ” text ë¬¸ìì—´ ìŠ¬ë¼ì´ìŠ¤ ì¸ìˆ˜ë¥¼ ë°›ì•„ lines ë©”ì„œë“œë¥¼ í˜¸ì¶œí•˜ëŠ”ë°, ì´ ë©”ì„œë“œëŠ” ë¬¸ìì—´ì˜ ì¤„ì— ëŒ€í•œ ë°˜ë³µìë¥¼ ë°˜í™˜í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤. ì´ í•¨ìˆ˜ëŠ” ì²« ë²ˆì§¸ ì¤„ì„ ê²€ì‚¬í•˜ê³  ì‹¶ì–´í•˜ë¯€ë¡œ ë°˜ë³µìì—ì„œ nextë¥¼ í˜¸ì¶œí•˜ì—¬ ì²« ë²ˆì§¸ ê°’ì„ ê°€ì ¸ì˜µë‹ˆë‹¤. textê°€ ë¹ˆ ë¬¸ìì—´ì´ë©´ next í˜¸ì¶œì€ Noneì„ ë°˜í™˜í•  ê²ƒì´ê³ , ì´ ê²½ìš° ìš°ë¦¬ëŠ” ?ë¥¼ ì‚¬ìš©í•˜ì—¬ ë©ˆì¶”ê³  last_char_of_first_lineì—ì„œ Noneì„ ë°˜í™˜í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤. textê°€ ë¹ˆ ë¬¸ìì—´ì´ ì•„ë‹ˆë¼ë©´ nextëŠ” textì˜ ì²« ë²ˆì§¸ ì¤„ì˜ ë¬¸ìì—´ ìŠ¬ë¼ì´ìŠ¤ë¥¼ í¬í•¨í•˜ëŠ” Some ê°’ì„ ë°˜í™˜í•  ê²ƒì…ë‹ˆë‹¤.

?ëŠ” ë¬¸ìì—´ ìŠ¬ë¼ì´ìŠ¤ë¥¼ ì¶”ì¶œí•˜ê³ , ìš°ë¦¬ëŠ” ê·¸ ë¬¸ìì—´ ìŠ¬ë¼ì´ìŠ¤ì— charsë¥¼ í˜¸ì¶œí•˜ì—¬ ë¬¸ìë“¤ì˜ ë°˜ë³µìë¥¼ ì–»ì„ ìˆ˜ ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤. ìš°ë¦¬ëŠ” ì´ ì²« ë²ˆì§¸ ì¤„ì˜ ë§ˆì§€ë§‰ ë¬¸ìì— ê´€ì‹¬ì´ ìˆìœ¼ë¯€ë¡œ lastë¥¼ í˜¸ì¶œí•˜ì—¬ ë°˜ë³µìì˜ ë§ˆì§€ë§‰ í•­ëª©ì„ ë°˜í™˜í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤. ì´ê²ƒì€ Optionì¸ë°, "\nhi"ì²˜ëŸ¼ textê°€ ë¹ˆ ì¤„ë¡œ ì‹œì‘í•˜ì§€ë§Œ ë‹¤ë¥¸ ì¤„ì— ë¬¸ìê°€ ìˆëŠ” ê²½ìš°ì™€ ê°™ì´ ì²« ë²ˆì§¸ ì¤„ì´ ë¹ˆ ë¬¸ìì—´ì¼ ê°€ëŠ¥ì„±ì´ ìˆê¸° ë•Œë¬¸ì…ë‹ˆë‹¤. ê·¸ëŸ¬ë‚˜ ì²« ë²ˆì§¸ ì¤„ì— ë§ˆì§€ë§‰ ë¬¸ìê°€ ìˆë‹¤ë©´ Some ë³€í˜•ìœ¼ë¡œ ë°˜í™˜ë  ê²ƒì…ë‹ˆë‹¤. ì¤‘ê°„ì— ìˆëŠ” ? ì—°ì‚°ìëŠ” ì´ ë¡œì§ì„ í‘œí˜„í•˜ëŠ” ê°„ê²°í•œ ë°©ë²•ì„ ì œê³µí•˜ì—¬ í•¨ìˆ˜ë¥¼ í•œ ì¤„ë¡œ êµ¬í˜„í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆê²Œ í•´ì¤ë‹ˆë‹¤. Optionì— ? ì—°ì‚°ìë¥¼ ì‚¬ìš©í•  ìˆ˜ ì—†ì—ˆë‹¤ë©´, ë” ë§ì€ ë©”ì„œë“œ í˜¸ì¶œì´ë‚˜ match í‘œí˜„ì‹ì„ ì‚¬ìš©í•˜ì—¬ ì´ ë¡œì§ì„ êµ¬í˜„í•´ì•¼ í–ˆì„ ê²ƒì…ë‹ˆë‹¤.

Resultë¥¼ ë°˜í™˜í•˜ëŠ” í•¨ìˆ˜ì—ì„œëŠ” Resultì— ? ì—°ì‚°ìë¥¼ ì‚¬ìš©í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆê³ , Optionì„ ë°˜í™˜í•˜ëŠ” í•¨ìˆ˜ì—ì„œëŠ” Optionì— ? ì—°ì‚°ìë¥¼ ì‚¬ìš©í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆì§€ë§Œ, ì„ì–´ì„œ ì‚¬ìš©í•  ìˆ˜ëŠ” ì—†ë‹¤ëŠ” ì ì— ìœ ì˜í•˜ì„¸ìš”. ? ì—°ì‚°ìëŠ” ìë™ìœ¼ë¡œ Resultë¥¼ Optionìœ¼ë¡œ ë˜ëŠ” ê·¸ ë°˜ëŒ€ë¡œ ë³€í™˜í•˜ì§€ ì•ŠìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤. ê·¸ëŸ° ê²½ìš°ì—ëŠ” Resultì˜ ok ë©”ì„œë“œë‚˜ Optionì˜ ok_or ë©”ì„œë“œì™€ ê°™ì€ ë©”ì„œë“œë¥¼ ì‚¬ìš©í•˜ì—¬ ëª…ì‹œì ìœ¼ë¡œ ë³€í™˜í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤.

ì§€ê¸ˆê¹Œì§€ ì‚¬ìš©í•œ ëª¨ë“  main í•¨ìˆ˜ëŠ” ()ë¥¼ ë°˜í™˜í–ˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤. main í•¨ìˆ˜ëŠ” ì‹¤í–‰ ê°€ëŠ¥í•œ í”„ë¡œê·¸ë¨ì˜ ì§„ì…ì ì´ì ì¢…ë£Œì ì´ê¸° ë•Œë¬¸ì— íŠ¹ë³„í•˜ë©°, í”„ë¡œê·¸ë¨ì´ ì˜ˆìƒëŒ€ë¡œ ë™ì‘í•˜ê¸° ìœ„í•´ ë°˜í™˜ íƒ€ì…ì´ ë  ìˆ˜ ìˆëŠ” ê²ƒì— ì œí•œì´ ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤.

ë‹¤í–‰íˆ mainì€ Result<(), E>ë„ ë°˜í™˜í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤. ëª©ë¡ 9-12ëŠ” ëª©ë¡ 9-10ì˜ ì½”ë“œë¥¼ ê°€ì§€ê³  ìˆì§€ë§Œ, mainì˜ ë°˜í™˜ íƒ€ì…ì„ Result<(), Box<dyn Error>>ë¡œ ë³€ê²½í•˜ê³  ëì— ë°˜í™˜ ê°’ Ok(())ë¥¼ ì¶”ê°€í–ˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤. ì´ ì½”ë“œëŠ” ì´ì œ ì»´íŒŒì¼ë  ê²ƒì…ë‹ˆë‹¤.

use std::error::Error;
use std::fs::File;

fn main() -> Result<(), Box<dyn Error>> {
    let greeting_file = File::open("hello.txt")?;

    Ok(())
}

The Box<dyn Error> type is a trait object, which weâ€™ll talk about in â€œUsing Trait Objects to Abstract over Shared Behaviorâ€ in Chapter 18. For now, you can read Box<dyn Error> to mean â€œany kind of error.â€ Using ? on a Result value in a main function with the error type Box<dyn Error> is allowed because it allows any Err value to be returned early. Even though the body of this main function will only ever return errors of type std::io::Error, by specifying Box<dyn Error>, this signature will continue to be correct even if more code that returns other errors is added to the body of main.

When a main function returns a Result<(), E>, the executable will exit with a value of 0 if main returns Ok(()) and will exit with a nonzero value if main returns an Err value. Executables written in C return integers when they exit: Programs that exit successfully return the integer 0, and programs that error return some integer other than 0. Rust also returns integers from executables to be compatible with this convention.

ìì‹ ì˜ íƒ€ì…ì— Termination íŠ¸ë ˆì´íŠ¸ë¥¼ êµ¬í˜„í•˜ëŠ” ê²ƒì— ëŒ€í•œ ìì„¸í•œ ë‚´ìš©ì€ í‘œì¤€ ë¼ì´ë¸ŒëŸ¬ë¦¬ ë¬¸ì„œë¥¼ ì°¸ì¡°í•˜ì„¸ìš”.

ì´ì œ panic!ì„ í˜¸ì¶œí•˜ê±°ë‚˜ Resultë¥¼ ë°˜í™˜í•˜ëŠ” ê²ƒì˜ ì„¸ë¶€ ì‚¬í•­ì— ëŒ€í•´ ë…¼ì˜í–ˆìœ¼ë¯€ë¡œ, ì–´ë–¤ ê²½ìš°ì— ì–´ë–¤ ê²ƒì„ ì‚¬ìš©í•˜ëŠ” ê²ƒì´ ì ì ˆí•œì§€ ê²°ì •í•˜ëŠ” ì£¼ì œë¡œ ëŒì•„ê°€ ë³´ê² ìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤.

panic!ì„ ì‚¬ìš©í• ì§€ ë§ì§€

So, how do you decide when you should call panic! and when you should return Result? When code panics, thereâ€™s no way to recover. You could call panic! for any error situation, whether thereâ€™s a possible way to recover or not, but then youâ€™re making the decision that a situation is unrecoverable on behalf of the calling code. When you choose to return a Result value, you give the calling code options. The calling code could choose to attempt to recover in a way thatâ€™s appropriate for its situation, or it could decide that an Err value in this case is unrecoverable, so it can call panic! and turn your recoverable error into an unrecoverable one. Therefore, returning Result is a good default choice when youâ€™re defining a function that might fail.

ì˜ˆì œ, í”„ë¡œí† íƒ€ì… ì½”ë“œ, í…ŒìŠ¤íŠ¸ì™€ ê°™ì€ ìƒí™©ì—ì„œëŠ” Resultë¥¼ ë°˜í™˜í•˜ëŠ” ëŒ€ì‹  íŒ¨ë‹‰ì„ ì¼ìœ¼í‚¤ëŠ” ì½”ë“œë¥¼ ì‘ì„±í•˜ëŠ” ê²ƒì´ ë” ì ì ˆí•©ë‹ˆë‹¤. ê·¸ ì´ìœ ë¥¼ ì•Œì•„ë³´ê³ , ì»´íŒŒì¼ëŸ¬ëŠ” ì‹¤íŒ¨ê°€ ë¶ˆê°€ëŠ¥í•˜ë‹¤ëŠ” ê²ƒì„ ì•Œ ìˆ˜ ì—†ì§€ë§Œ ì‚¬ëŒì€ ì•Œ ìˆ˜ ìˆëŠ” ìƒí™©ì— ëŒ€í•´ ë…¼ì˜í•´ ë³´ê² ìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤. ì´ ì¥ì€ ë¼ì´ë¸ŒëŸ¬ë¦¬ ì½”ë“œì—ì„œ íŒ¨ë‹‰ì„ ì¼ìœ¼í‚¬ì§€ ì—¬ë¶€ë¥¼ ê²°ì •í•˜ëŠ” ë°©ë²•ì— ëŒ€í•œ ëª‡ ê°€ì§€ ì¼ë°˜ì ì¸ ì§€ì¹¨ìœ¼ë¡œ ë§ˆë¬´ë¦¬í•  ê²ƒì…ë‹ˆë‹¤.

ì˜ˆì œ, í”„ë¡œí† íƒ€ì… ì½”ë“œ, ê·¸ë¦¬ê³  í…ŒìŠ¤íŠ¸

ì–´ë–¤ ê°œë…ì„ ì„¤ëª…í•˜ê¸° ìœ„í•´ ì˜ˆì œë¥¼ ì‘ì„±í•  ë•Œ, ê²¬ê³ í•œ ì—ëŸ¬ ì²˜ë¦¬ ì½”ë“œê¹Œì§€ í¬í•¨í•˜ë©´ ì˜ˆì œê°€ ëœ ëª…í™•í•´ì§ˆ ìˆ˜ ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤. ì˜ˆì œì—ì„œ íŒ¨ë‹‰ì„ ì¼ìœ¼í‚¬ ìˆ˜ ìˆëŠ” unwrap ê°™ì€ ë©”ì„œë“œë¥¼ í˜¸ì¶œí•˜ëŠ” ê²ƒì€ ì—¬ëŸ¬ë¶„ì´ ì• í”Œë¦¬ì¼€ì´ì…˜ì—ì„œ ì—ëŸ¬ë¥¼ ì²˜ë¦¬í•˜ê³ ì í•˜ëŠ” ë°©ì‹ì— ëŒ€í•œ ìë¦¬ í‘œì‹œìë¡œ ì´í•´ë˜ë©°, ì´ëŠ” ë‚˜ë¨¸ì§€ ì½”ë“œê°€ ìˆ˜í–‰í•˜ëŠ” ì‘ì—…ì— ë”°ë¼ ë‹¬ë¼ì§ˆ ìˆ˜ ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤.

Similarly, the unwrap and expect methods are very handy when youâ€™re prototyping and youâ€™re not yet ready to decide how to handle errors. They leave clear markers in your code for when youâ€™re ready to make your program more robust.

í…ŒìŠ¤íŠ¸ì—ì„œ ë©”ì„œë“œ í˜¸ì¶œì´ ì‹¤íŒ¨í•˜ë©´, í•´ë‹¹ ë©”ì„œë“œê°€ í…ŒìŠ¤íŠ¸ ëŒ€ìƒ ê¸°ëŠ¥ì´ ì•„ë‹ˆë”ë¼ë„ ì „ì²´ í…ŒìŠ¤íŠ¸ê°€ ì‹¤íŒ¨í•˜ê¸°ë¥¼ ì›í•  ê²ƒì…ë‹ˆë‹¤. panic!ì€ í…ŒìŠ¤íŠ¸ê°€ ì‹¤íŒ¨ë¡œ í‘œì‹œë˜ëŠ” ë°©ì‹ì´ë¯€ë¡œ, unwrapì´ë‚˜ expectë¥¼ í˜¸ì¶œí•˜ëŠ” ê²ƒì´ ì •í™•íˆ ì¼ì–´ë‚˜ì•¼ í•  ì¼ì…ë‹ˆë‹¤.

When You Have More Information Than the Compiler

It would also be appropriate to call expect when you have some other logic that ensures that the Result will have an Ok value, but the logic isnâ€™t something the compiler understands. Youâ€™ll still have a Result value that you need to handle: Whatever operation youâ€™re calling still has the possibility of failing in general, even though itâ€™s logically impossible in your particular situation. If you can ensure by manually inspecting the code that youâ€™ll never have an Err variant, itâ€™s perfectly acceptable to call expect and document the reason you think youâ€™ll never have an Err variant in the argument text. Hereâ€™s an example:

fn main() {
    use std::net::IpAddr;

    let home: IpAddr = "127.0.0.1"
        .parse()
        .expect("í•˜ë“œì½”ë”©ëœ IP ì£¼ì†ŒëŠ” ìœ íš¨í•´ì•¼ í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤");
}

Weâ€™re creating an IpAddr instance by parsing a hardcoded string. We can see that 127.0.0.1 is a valid IP address, so itâ€™s acceptable to use expect here. However, having a hardcoded, valid string doesnâ€™t change the return type of the parse method: We still get a Result value, and the compiler will still make us handle the Result as if the Err variant is a possibility because the compiler isnâ€™t smart enough to see that this string is always a valid IP address. If the IP address string came from a user rather than being hardcoded into the program and therefore did have a possibility of failure, weâ€™d definitely want to handle the Result in a more robust way instead. Mentioning the assumption that this IP address is hardcoded will prompt us to change expect to better error-handling code if, in the future, we need to get the IP address from some other source instead.

ì—ëŸ¬ ì²˜ë¦¬ ê°€ì´ë“œë¼ì¸

ì½”ë“œê°€ ë‚˜ìœ ìƒíƒœì— ë¹ ì§ˆ ìˆ˜ ìˆì„ ë•Œ ì½”ë“œê°€ íŒ¨ë‹‰ì„ ì¼ìœ¼í‚¤ë„ë¡ í•˜ëŠ” ê²ƒì´ ì¢‹ìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤. ì´ ë¬¸ë§¥ì—ì„œ _ë‚˜ìœ ìƒíƒœ_ë€ ìœ íš¨í•˜ì§€ ì•Šì€ ê°’, ëª¨ìˆœë˜ëŠ” ê°’, ë˜ëŠ” ëˆ„ë½ëœ ê°’ì´ ì½”ë“œì— ì „ë‹¬ë˜ëŠ” ê²ƒê³¼ ê°™ì´ ì¼ë¶€ ê°€ì •, ë³´ì¥, ê³„ì•½ ë˜ëŠ” ë¶ˆë³€ì„±ì´ ê¹¨ì§„ ê²½ìš°ë¥¼ ë§í•˜ë©°, ì—¬ê¸°ì— ë”í•´ ë‹¤ìŒ ì¤‘ í•˜ë‚˜ ì´ìƒì— í•´ë‹¹í•  ë•Œì…ë‹ˆë‹¤:

  • ë‚˜ìœ ìƒíƒœëŠ” ì‚¬ìš©ìê°€ ì˜ëª»ëœ í˜•ì‹ì˜ ë°ì´í„°ë¥¼ ì…ë ¥í•˜ëŠ” ê²ƒì²˜ëŸ¼ ê°€ë” ì¼ì–´ë‚  ê°€ëŠ¥ì„±ì´ ìˆëŠ” ê²ƒì´ ì•„ë‹ˆë¼ ì˜ˆìƒì¹˜ ëª»í•œ ê²ƒì…ë‹ˆë‹¤.
  • ì´ ì‹œì  ì´í›„ì˜ ì½”ë“œëŠ” ë§¤ ë‹¨ê³„ë§ˆë‹¤ ë¬¸ì œë¥¼ í™•ì¸í•˜ëŠ” ëŒ€ì‹  ì´ ë‚˜ìœ ìƒíƒœì— ìˆì§€ ì•Šë‹¤ëŠ” ì ì— ì˜ì¡´í•´ì•¼ í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤.
  • ì‚¬ìš©í•˜ëŠ” íƒ€ì…ì— ì´ ì •ë³´ë¥¼ ì¸ì½”ë”©í•  ì¢‹ì€ ë°©ë²•ì´ ì—†ìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤. 18ì¥ì˜ â€œìƒíƒœì™€ ë™ì‘ì„ íƒ€ì…ìœ¼ë¡œ ì¸ì½”ë”©í•˜ê¸°â€ì—ì„œ ì´ê²ƒì´ ë¬´ìŠ¨ ëœ»ì¸ì§€ ì˜ˆì œë¥¼ í†µí•´ ì‚´í´ë³¼ ê²ƒì…ë‹ˆë‹¤.

If someone calls your code and passes in values that donâ€™t make sense, itâ€™s best to return an error if you can so that the user of the library can decide what they want to do in that case. However, in cases where continuing could be insecure or harmful, the best choice might be to call panic! and alert the person using your library to the bug in their code so that they can fix it during development. Similarly, panic! is often appropriate if youâ€™re calling external code that is out of your control and returns an invalid state that you have no way of fixing.

í•˜ì§€ë§Œ ì‹¤íŒ¨ê°€ ì˜ˆìƒë  ë•ŒëŠ” panic! í˜¸ì¶œë³´ë‹¤ëŠ” Resultë¥¼ ë°˜í™˜í•˜ëŠ” ê²ƒì´ ë” ì ì ˆí•©ë‹ˆë‹¤. íŒŒì„œì— ì˜ëª»ëœ í˜•ì‹ì˜ ë°ì´í„°ê°€ ì£¼ì–´ì§€ê±°ë‚˜ HTTP ìš”ì²­ì´ ì†ë„ ì œí•œì— ë„ë‹¬í–ˆìŒì„ ë‚˜íƒ€ë‚´ëŠ” ìƒíƒœë¥¼ ë°˜í™˜í•˜ëŠ” ê²½ìš°ë¥¼ ì˜ˆë¡œ ë“¤ ìˆ˜ ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤. ì´ëŸ¬í•œ ê²½ìš° Resultë¥¼ ë°˜í™˜í•˜ëŠ” ê²ƒì€ ì‹¤íŒ¨ê°€ ì˜ˆìƒë˜ëŠ” ê°€ëŠ¥ì„±ì´ë©° í˜¸ì¶œí•˜ëŠ” ì½”ë“œê°€ ì´ë¥¼ ì²˜ë¦¬í•˜ëŠ” ë°©ë²•ì„ ê²°ì •í•´ì•¼ í•¨ì„ ë‚˜íƒ€ëƒ…ë‹ˆë‹¤.

When your code performs an operation that could put a user at risk if itâ€™s called using invalid values, your code should verify the values are valid first and panic if the values arenâ€™t valid. This is mostly for safety reasons: Attempting to operate on invalid data can expose your code to vulnerabilities. This is the main reason the standard library will call panic! if you attempt an out-of-bounds memory access: Trying to access memory that doesnâ€™t belong to the current data structure is a common security problem. Functions often have contracts: Their behavior is only guaranteed if the inputs meet particular requirements. Panicking when the contract is violated makes sense because a contract violation always indicates a caller-side bug, and itâ€™s not a kind of error you want the calling code to have to explicitly handle. In fact, thereâ€™s no reasonable way for calling code to recover; the calling programmers need to fix the code. Contracts for a function, especially when a violation will cause a panic, should be explained in the API documentation for the function.

However, having lots of error checks in all of your functions would be verbose and annoying. Fortunately, you can use Rustâ€™s type system (and thus the type checking done by the compiler) to do many of the checks for you. If your function has a particular type as a parameter, you can proceed with your codeâ€™s logic knowing that the compiler has already ensured that you have a valid value. For example, if you have a type rather than an Option, your program expects to have something rather than nothing. Your code then doesnâ€™t have to handle two cases for the Some and None variants: It will only have one case for definitely having a value. Code trying to pass nothing to your function wonâ€™t even compile, so your function doesnâ€™t have to check for that case at runtime. Another example is using an unsigned integer type such as u32, which ensures that the parameter is never negative.

Custom Types for Validation

Letâ€™s take the idea of using Rustâ€™s type system to ensure that we have a valid value one step further and look at creating a custom type for validation. Recall the guessing game in Chapter 2 in which our code asked the user to guess a number between 1 and 100. We never validated that the userâ€™s guess was between those numbers before checking it against our secret number; we only validated that the guess was positive. In this case, the consequences were not very dire: Our output of â€œToo highâ€ or â€œToo lowâ€ would still be correct. But it would be a useful enhancement to guide the user toward valid guesses and have different behavior when the user guesses a number thatâ€™s out of range versus when the user types, for example, letters instead.

ì´ë¥¼ ìˆ˜í–‰í•˜ëŠ” í•œ ê°€ì§€ ë°©ë²•ì€ ì¶”ì¸¡ì„ u32 ëŒ€ì‹  i32ë¡œ íŒŒì‹±í•˜ì—¬ ì ì¬ì ìœ¼ë¡œ ìŒìˆ˜ë¥¼ í—ˆìš©í•˜ê³ , ê·¸ëŸ° ë‹¤ìŒ ë‹¤ìŒê³¼ ê°™ì´ ìˆ«ìê°€ ë²”ìœ„ ë‚´ì— ìˆëŠ”ì§€ í™•ì¸í•˜ëŠ” ê²€ì‚¬ë¥¼ ì¶”ê°€í•˜ëŠ” ê²ƒì…ë‹ˆë‹¤:

use rand::Rng;
use std::cmp::Ordering;
use std::io;

fn main() {
    println!("ìˆ«ìë¥¼ ë§ì¶°ë³´ì„¸ìš”!");

    let secret_number = rand::thread_rng().gen_range(1..=100);

    loop {
        // --ìƒëµ--

        println!(ì¶”ì¸¡ì„ ì…ë ¥í•˜ì„¸ìš”.);

        let mut guess = String::new();

        io::stdin()
            .read_line(&mut guess)
            .expect("ì¤„ ì½ê¸° ì‹¤íŒ¨");

        let guess: i32 = match guess.trim().parse() {
            Ok(num) => num,
            Err(_) => continue,
        };

        if guess < 1 || guess > 100 {
            println!("ë¹„ë°€ ìˆ«ìëŠ” 1ì—ì„œ 100 ì‚¬ì´ì…ë‹ˆë‹¤.");
            continue;
        }

        match guess.cmp(&secret_number) {
            // --ìƒëµ--
            Ordering::Less => println!("ë„ˆë¬´ ì‘ì•„ìš”!"),
            Ordering::Greater => println!("ë„ˆë¬´ ì»¤ìš”!"),
            Ordering::Equal => {
                println!("ë‹¹ì‹ ì´ ì´ê²¼ìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤!");
                break;
            }
        }
    }
}

if í‘œí˜„ì‹ì€ ê°’ì´ ë²”ìœ„ë¥¼ ë²—ì–´ë‚¬ëŠ”ì§€ í™•ì¸í•˜ê³ , ì‚¬ìš©ìì—ê²Œ ë¬¸ì œë¥¼ ì•Œë¦¬ê³ , continueë¥¼ í˜¸ì¶œí•˜ì—¬ ë£¨í”„ì˜ ë‹¤ìŒ ë°˜ë³µì„ ì‹œì‘í•˜ê³  ë‹¤ë¥¸ ì¶”ì¸¡ì„ ìš”ì²­í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤. if í‘œí˜„ì‹ ì´í›„ì—ëŠ” guessê°€ 1ì—ì„œ 100 ì‚¬ì´ì„ì„ ì•Œê³  guessì™€ ë¹„ë°€ ìˆ«ì ê°„ì˜ ë¹„êµë¥¼ ì§„í–‰í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤.

However, this is not an ideal solution: If it were absolutely critical that the program only operated on values between 1 and 100, and it had many functions with this requirement, having a check like this in every function would be tedious (and might impact performance).

Instead, we can make a new type in a dedicated module and put the validations in a function to create an instance of the type rather than repeating the validations everywhere. That way, itâ€™s safe for functions to use the new type in their signatures and confidently use the values they receive. Listing 9-13 shows one way to define a Guess type that will only create an instance of Guess if the new function receives a value between 1 and 100.

#![allow(unused)]
fn main() {
pub struct Guess {
    value: i32,
}

impl Guess {
    pub fn new(value: i32) -> Guess {
        if value < 1 || value > 100 {
            panic!(ì¶”ì¸¡ ê°’ì€ 1ì—ì„œ 100 ì‚¬ì´ì—¬ì•¼ í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤. {value}ë¥¼ ë°›ì•˜ìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤.);
        }

        Guess { value }
    }

    pub fn value(&self) -> i32 {
        self.value
    }
}
}

Note that this code in src/guessing_game.rs depends on adding a module declaration mod guessing_game; in src/lib.rs that we havenâ€™t shown here. Within this new moduleâ€™s file, we define a struct named Guess that has a field named value that holds an i32. This is where the number will be stored.

Then, we implement an associated function named new on Guess that creates instances of Guess values. The new function is defined to have one parameter named value of type i32 and to return a Guess. The code in the body of the new function tests value to make sure itâ€™s between 1 and 100. If value doesnâ€™t pass this test, we make a panic! call, which will alert the programmer who is writing the calling code that they have a bug they need to fix, because creating a Guess with a value outside this range would violate the contract that Guess::new is relying on. The conditions in which Guess::new might panic should be discussed in its public-facing API documentation; weâ€™ll cover documentation conventions indicating the possibility of a panic! in the API documentation that you create in Chapter 14. If value does pass the test, we create a new Guess with its value field set to the value parameter and return the Guess.

Next, we implement a method named value that borrows self, doesnâ€™t have any other parameters, and returns an i32. This kind of method is sometimes called a getter because its purpose is to get some data from its fields and return it. This public method is necessary because the value field of the Guess struct is private. Itâ€™s important that the value field be private so that code using the Guess struct is not allowed to set value directly: Code outside the guessing_game module must use the Guess::new function to create an instance of Guess, thereby ensuring that thereâ€™s no way for a Guess to have a value that hasnâ€™t been checked by the conditions in the Guess::new function.

ë§¤ê°œë³€ìˆ˜ë¥¼ ê°€ì§€ê±°ë‚˜ 1ì—ì„œ 100 ì‚¬ì´ì˜ ìˆ«ìë§Œ ë°˜í™˜í•˜ëŠ” í•¨ìˆ˜ëŠ” ì‹œê·¸ë‹ˆì²˜ì—ì„œ i32 ëŒ€ì‹  Guessë¥¼ ë°›ê±°ë‚˜ ë°˜í™˜í•œë‹¤ê³  ì„ ì–¸í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆìœ¼ë©°, ë³¸ë¬¸ì—ì„œ ì¶”ê°€ì ì¸ ê²€ì‚¬ë¥¼ í•  í•„ìš”ê°€ ì—†ìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤.

ìš”ì•½

ëŸ¬ìŠ¤íŠ¸ì˜ ì˜¤ë¥˜ ì²˜ë¦¬ ê¸°ëŠ¥ì€ ë” ê²¬ê³ í•œ ì½”ë“œë¥¼ ì‘ì„±í•˜ëŠ” ë° ë„ì›€ì´ ë˜ë„ë¡ ì„¤ê³„ë˜ì—ˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤. panic! ë§¤í¬ë¡œëŠ” í”„ë¡œê·¸ë¨ì´ ì²˜ë¦¬í•  ìˆ˜ ì—†ëŠ” ìƒíƒœì— ìˆìŒì„ ì•Œë¦¬ê³ , ìœ íš¨í•˜ì§€ ì•Šê±°ë‚˜ ì˜ëª»ëœ ê°’ìœ¼ë¡œ ê³„ì† ì§„í–‰í•˜ë ¤ê³  ì‹œë„í•˜ëŠ” ëŒ€ì‹  í”„ë¡œì„¸ìŠ¤ë¥¼ ì¤‘ì§€í•˜ë„ë¡ ì§€ì‹œí•©ë‹ˆë‹¤. Result ì—´ê±°í˜•ì€ ëŸ¬ìŠ¤íŠ¸ì˜ íƒ€ì… ì‹œìŠ¤í…œì„ ì‚¬ìš©í•˜ì—¬ ì½”ë“œê°€ ë³µêµ¬í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆëŠ” ë°©ì‹ìœ¼ë¡œ ì‘ì—…ì´ ì‹¤íŒ¨í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆìŒì„ ë‚˜íƒ€ëƒ…ë‹ˆë‹¤. Resultë¥¼ ì‚¬ìš©í•˜ì—¬ ì½”ë“œë¥¼ í˜¸ì¶œí•˜ëŠ” ì½”ë“œì— ì ì¬ì ì¸ ì„±ê³µ ë˜ëŠ” ì‹¤íŒ¨ë¥¼ ì²˜ë¦¬í•´ì•¼ í•œë‹¤ê³  ì•Œë¦´ ìˆ˜ ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤. ì ì ˆí•œ ìƒí™©ì—ì„œ panic!ê³¼ Resultë¥¼ ì‚¬ìš©í•˜ë©´ í”¼í•  ìˆ˜ ì—†ëŠ” ë¬¸ì œì— ì§ë©´í–ˆì„ ë•Œ ì½”ë“œë¥¼ ë” ì•ˆì •ì ìœ¼ë¡œ ë§Œë“¤ ìˆ˜ ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤.

ì´ì œ í‘œì¤€ ë¼ì´ë¸ŒëŸ¬ë¦¬ê°€ Option ë° Result ì—´ê±°í˜•ê³¼ í•¨ê»˜ ì œë„¤ë¦­ì„ ì‚¬ìš©í•˜ëŠ” ìœ ìš©í•œ ë°©ë²•ì„ ë³´ì•˜ìœ¼ë‹ˆ, ì œë„¤ë¦­ì´ ì–´ë–»ê²Œ ì‘ë™í•˜ê³  ì½”ë“œì—ì„œ ì–´ë–»ê²Œ ì‚¬ìš©í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆëŠ”ì§€ì— ëŒ€í•´ ì´ì•¼ê¸°í•  ê²ƒì…ë‹ˆë‹¤.

ì œë„¤ë¦­ íƒ€ì…, íŠ¸ë ˆì´íŠ¸, ë¼ì´í”„íƒ€ì„

ëª¨ë“  í”„ë¡œê·¸ë˜ë° ì–¸ì–´ì—ëŠ” ê°œë…ì˜ ì¤‘ë³µì„ íš¨ê³¼ì ìœ¼ë¡œ ì²˜ë¦¬í•˜ê¸° ìœ„í•œ ë„êµ¬ê°€ ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤. ëŸ¬ìŠ¤íŠ¸ì—ì„œ ê·¸ëŸ¬í•œ ë„êµ¬ ì¤‘ í•˜ë‚˜ëŠ” _ì œë„¤ë¦­_ì…ë‹ˆë‹¤. ì œë„¤ë¦­ì€ êµ¬ì²´ì ì¸ íƒ€ì… ë˜ëŠ” ë‹¤ë¥¸ ì†ì„±ì„ ìœ„í•œ ì¶”ìƒì ì¸ ëŒ€ì²´ë¬¼ì…ë‹ˆë‹¤. ìš°ë¦¬ëŠ” ì½”ë“œë¥¼ ì»´íŒŒì¼í•˜ê³  ì‹¤í–‰í•  ë•Œ ë¬´ì—‡ì´ ê·¸ ìë¦¬ì— ì˜¬ì§€ ì•Œì§€ ëª»í•˜ë”ë¼ë„ ì œë„¤ë¦­ì˜ ë™ì‘ì´ë‚˜ ë‹¤ë¥¸ ì œë„¤ë¦­ê³¼ì˜ ê´€ê³„ë¥¼ í‘œí˜„í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤.

Functions can take parameters of some generic type, instead of a concrete type like i32 or String, in the same way they take parameters with unknown values to run the same code on multiple concrete values. In fact, we already used generics in Chapter 6 with Option<T>, in Chapter 8 with Vec<T> and HashMap<K, V>, and in Chapter 9 with Result<T, E>. In this chapter, youâ€™ll explore how to define your own types, functions, and methods with generics!

First, weâ€™ll review how to extract a function to reduce code duplication. Weâ€™ll then use the same technique to make a generic function from two functions that differ only in the types of their parameters. Weâ€™ll also explain how to use generic types in struct and enum definitions.

Then, youâ€™ll learn how to use traits to define behavior in a generic way. You can combine traits with generic types to constrain a generic type to accept only those types that have a particular behavior, as opposed to just any type.

Finally, weâ€™ll discuss lifetimes: a variety of generics that give the compiler information about how references relate to each other. Lifetimes allow us to give the compiler enough information about borrowed values so that it can ensure that references will be valid in more situations than it could without our help.

í•¨ìˆ˜ ì¶”ì¶œì„ í†µí•œ ì¤‘ë³µ ì œê±°

Generics allow us to replace specific types with a placeholder that represents multiple types to remove code duplication. Before diving into generics syntax, letâ€™s first look at how to remove duplication in a way that doesnâ€™t involve generic types by extracting a function that replaces specific values with a placeholder that represents multiple values. Then, weâ€™ll apply the same technique to extract a generic function! By looking at how to recognize duplicated code you can extract into a function, youâ€™ll start to recognize duplicated code that can use generics.

ëª©ë¡ 10-1ì— ìˆëŠ”, ëª©ë¡ì—ì„œ ê°€ì¥ í° ìˆ«ìë¥¼ ì°¾ëŠ” ì§§ì€ í”„ë¡œê·¸ë¨ìœ¼ë¡œ ì‹œì‘í•˜ê² ìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤.

fn main() {
    let number_list = vec![34, 50, 25, 100, 65];

    let mut largest = &number_list[0];

    for number in &number_list {
        if number > largest {
            largest = number;
        }
    }

    println!("ê°€ì¥ í° ìˆ«ìëŠ” {largest}ì…ë‹ˆë‹¤");
    assert_eq!(*largest, 100);
}

ìš°ë¦¬ëŠ” number_list ë³€ìˆ˜ì— ì •ìˆ˜ ëª©ë¡ì„ ì €ì¥í•˜ê³ , ëª©ë¡ì˜ ì²« ë²ˆì§¸ ìˆ«ìì— ëŒ€í•œ ì°¸ì¡°ë¥¼ largestë¼ëŠ” ë³€ìˆ˜ì— ì €ì¥í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤. ê·¸ëŸ° ë‹¤ìŒ ëª©ë¡ì˜ ëª¨ë“  ìˆ«ìë¥¼ ë°˜ë³µí•˜ë©°, í˜„ì¬ ìˆ«ìê°€ largestì— ì €ì¥ëœ ìˆ«ìë³´ë‹¤ í¬ë©´ í•´ë‹¹ ë³€ìˆ˜ì˜ ì°¸ì¡°ë¥¼ êµì²´í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤. ê·¸ëŸ¬ë‚˜ í˜„ì¬ ìˆ«ìê°€ ì§€ê¸ˆê¹Œì§€ ë³¸ ê°€ì¥ í° ìˆ«ìë³´ë‹¤ ì‘ê±°ë‚˜ ê°™ìœ¼ë©´ ë³€ìˆ˜ëŠ” ë³€ê²½ë˜ì§€ ì•Šê³ , ì½”ë“œëŠ” ëª©ë¡ì˜ ë‹¤ìŒ ìˆ«ìë¡œ ì´ë™í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤. ëª©ë¡ì˜ ëª¨ë“  ìˆ«ìë¥¼ ê³ ë ¤í•œ í›„, largestëŠ” ê°€ì¥ í° ìˆ«ìë¥¼ ì°¸ì¡°í•´ì•¼ í•˜ë©°, ì´ ê²½ìš° 100ì…ë‹ˆë‹¤.

ì´ì œ ë‘ ê°œì˜ ë‹¤ë¥¸ ìˆ«ì ëª©ë¡ì—ì„œ ê°€ì¥ í° ìˆ«ìë¥¼ ì°¾ëŠ” ì‘ì—…ì„ ë§¡ê²Œ ë˜ì—ˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤. ì´ë¥¼ ìœ„í•´ ëª©ë¡ 10-1ì˜ ì½”ë“œë¥¼ ë³µì œí•˜ê³  í”„ë¡œê·¸ë¨ì˜ ë‘ ë‹¤ë¥¸ ìœ„ì¹˜ì—ì„œ ë™ì¼í•œ ë¡œì§ì„ ì‚¬ìš©í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤. ì´ëŠ” ëª©ë¡ 10-2ì— ë‚˜ì™€ ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤.

fn main() {
    let number_list = vec![34, 50, 25, 100, 65];

    let mut largest = &number_list[0];

    for number in &number_list {
        if number > largest {
            largest = number;
        }
    }

    println!("ê°€ì¥ í° ìˆ«ìëŠ” {largest}ì…ë‹ˆë‹¤");

    let number_list = vec![102, 34, 6000, 89, 54, 2, 43, 8];

    let mut largest = &number_list[0];

    for number in &number_list {
        if number > largest {
            largest = number;
        }
    }

    println!("ê°€ì¥ í° ìˆ«ìëŠ” {largest}ì…ë‹ˆë‹¤");
}

Although this code works, duplicating code is tedious and error-prone. We also have to remember to update the code in multiple places when we want to change it.

ì´ ì¤‘ë³µì„ ì œê±°í•˜ê¸° ìœ„í•´, ë§¤ê°œë³€ìˆ˜ë¡œ ì „ë‹¬ëœ ëª¨ë“  ì •ìˆ˜ ëª©ë¡ì— ëŒ€í•´ ì‘ë™í•˜ëŠ” í•¨ìˆ˜ë¥¼ ì •ì˜í•˜ì—¬ ì¶”ìƒí™”ë¥¼ ìƒì„±í•  ê²ƒì…ë‹ˆë‹¤. ì´ í•´ê²°ì±…ì€ ì½”ë“œë¥¼ ë” ëª…í™•í•˜ê²Œ ë§Œë“¤ê³ , ëª©ë¡ì—ì„œ ê°€ì¥ í° ìˆ«ìë¥¼ ì°¾ëŠ” ê°œë…ì„ ì¶”ìƒì ìœ¼ë¡œ í‘œí˜„í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆë„ë¡ í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤.

In Listing 10-3, we extract the code that finds the largest number into a function named largest. Then, we call the function to find the largest number in the two lists from Listing 10-2. We could also use the function on any other list of i32 values we might have in the future.

fn largest(list: &[i32]) -> &i32 {
    let mut largest = &list[0];

    for item in list {
        if item > largest {
            largest = item;
        }
    }

    largest
}

fn main() {
    let number_list = vec![34, 50, 25, 100, 65];

    let result = largest(&number_list);
    println!("ê°€ì¥ í° ìˆ«ìëŠ” {result}ì…ë‹ˆë‹¤");
    assert_eq!(*result, 100);

    let number_list = vec![102, 34, 6000, 89, 54, 2, 43, 8];

    let result = largest(&number_list);
    println!("ê°€ì¥ í° ìˆ«ìëŠ” {result}ì…ë‹ˆë‹¤");
    assert_eq!(*result, 6000);
}

largest í•¨ìˆ˜ëŠ” listë¼ëŠ” ë§¤ê°œë³€ìˆ˜ë¥¼ ê°€ì§€ë©°, ì´ëŠ” í•¨ìˆ˜ì— ì „ë‹¬í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆëŠ” i32 ê°’ì˜ êµ¬ì²´ì ì¸ ìŠ¬ë¼ì´ìŠ¤ë¥¼ ë‚˜íƒ€ëƒ…ë‹ˆë‹¤. ê²°ê³¼ì ìœ¼ë¡œ, í•¨ìˆ˜ë¥¼ í˜¸ì¶œí•  ë•Œ ì½”ë“œëŠ” ìš°ë¦¬ê°€ ì „ë‹¬í•˜ëŠ” íŠ¹ì • ê°’ì— ëŒ€í•´ ì‹¤í–‰ë©ë‹ˆë‹¤.

ìš”ì•½í•˜ìë©´, ëª©ë¡ 10-2ì˜ ì½”ë“œë¥¼ ëª©ë¡ 10-3ìœ¼ë¡œ ë³€ê²½í•˜ê¸° ìœ„í•´ ìˆ˜í–‰í•œ ë‹¨ê³„ëŠ” ë‹¤ìŒê³¼ ê°™ìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤:

  1. ì¤‘ë³µ ì½”ë“œ ì‹ë³„.
  2. ì¤‘ë³µ ì½”ë“œë¥¼ í•¨ìˆ˜ì˜ ë³¸ë¬¸ìœ¼ë¡œ ì¶”ì¶œí•˜ê³ , í•¨ìˆ˜ ì‹œê·¸ë‹ˆì²˜ì— í•´ë‹¹ ì½”ë“œì˜ ì…ë ¥ ë° ë°˜í™˜ ê°’ì„ ì§€ì •í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤.
  3. ì¤‘ë³µëœ ì½”ë“œì˜ ë‘ ì¸ìŠ¤í„´ìŠ¤ë¥¼ í•¨ìˆ˜ë¥¼ í˜¸ì¶œí•˜ë„ë¡ ì—…ë°ì´íŠ¸í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤.

ë‹¤ìŒìœ¼ë¡œ, ì´ì™€ ë™ì¼í•œ ë‹¨ê³„ë¥¼ ì œë„¤ë¦­ê³¼ í•¨ê»˜ ì‚¬ìš©í•˜ì—¬ ì½”ë“œ ì¤‘ë³µì„ ì¤„ì¼ ê²ƒì…ë‹ˆë‹¤. í•¨ìˆ˜ ë³¸ë¬¸ì´ íŠ¹ì • ê°’ ëŒ€ì‹  ì¶”ìƒì ì¸ listì— ëŒ€í•´ ì‘ë™í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆëŠ” ê²ƒê³¼ ë§ˆì°¬ê°€ì§€ë¡œ, ì œë„¤ë¦­ì€ ì½”ë“œê°€ ì¶”ìƒì ì¸ íƒ€ì…ì— ëŒ€í•´ ì‘ë™í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆë„ë¡ í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤.

ì˜ˆë¥¼ ë“¤ì–´, i32 ê°’ ìŠ¬ë¼ì´ìŠ¤ì—ì„œ ê°€ì¥ í° í•­ëª©ì„ ì°¾ëŠ” í•¨ìˆ˜ì™€ char ê°’ ìŠ¬ë¼ì´ìŠ¤ì—ì„œ ê°€ì¥ í° í•­ëª©ì„ ì°¾ëŠ” ë‘ í•¨ìˆ˜ê°€ ìˆë‹¤ê³  ê°€ì •í•´ ë´…ì‹œë‹¤. ì´ ì¤‘ë³µì„ ì–´ë–»ê²Œ ì œê±°í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆì„ê¹Œìš”? ì•Œì•„ë´…ì‹œë‹¤!

ì œë„¤ë¦­ ë°ì´í„° íƒ€ì…

We use generics to create definitions for items like function signatures or structs, which we can then use with many different concrete data types. Letâ€™s first look at how to define functions, structs, enums, and methods using generics. Then, weâ€™ll discuss how generics affect code performance.

í•¨ìˆ˜ ì •ì˜ì—ì„œ

ì œë„¤ë¦­ì„ ì‚¬ìš©í•˜ëŠ” í•¨ìˆ˜ë¥¼ ì •ì˜í•  ë•Œ, ì¼ë°˜ì ìœ¼ë¡œ ë§¤ê°œë³€ìˆ˜ì™€ ë°˜í™˜ ê°’ì˜ ë°ì´í„° íƒ€ì…ì„ ì§€ì •í•˜ëŠ” í•¨ìˆ˜ ì‹œê·¸ë‹ˆì²˜ì— ì œë„¤ë¦­ì„ ë°°ì¹˜í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤. ì´ë ‡ê²Œ í•˜ë©´ ì½”ë“œê°€ ë” ìœ ì—°í•´ì§€ê³ , ì½”ë“œ ì¤‘ë³µì„ ë°©ì§€í•˜ë©´ì„œ í•¨ìˆ˜ í˜¸ì¶œìì—ê²Œ ë” ë§ì€ ê¸°ëŠ¥ì„ ì œê³µí•©ë‹ˆë‹¤.

ìš°ë¦¬ì˜ largest í•¨ìˆ˜ë¥¼ ê³„ì†í•´ì„œ ì‚´í´ë³´ë©´, ëª©ë¡ 10-4ëŠ” ìŠ¬ë¼ì´ìŠ¤ì—ì„œ ê°€ì¥ í° ê°’ì„ ì°¾ëŠ” ë‘ í•¨ìˆ˜ë¥¼ ë³´ì—¬ì¤ë‹ˆë‹¤. ê·¸ëŸ° ë‹¤ìŒ ì´ í•¨ìˆ˜ë“¤ì„ ì œë„¤ë¦­ì„ ì‚¬ìš©í•˜ëŠ” ë‹¨ì¼ í•¨ìˆ˜ë¡œ ê²°í•©í•  ê²ƒì…ë‹ˆë‹¤.

fn largest_i32(list: &[i32]) -> &i32 {
    let mut largest = &list[0];

    for item in list {
        if item > largest {
            largest = item;
        }
    }

    largest
}

fn largest_char(list: &[char]) -> &char {
    let mut largest = &list[0];

    for item in list {
        if item > largest {
            largest = item;
        }
    }

    largest
}

fn main() {
    let number_list = vec![34, 50, 25, 100, 65];

    let result = largest_i32(&number_list);
    println!("ê°€ì¥ í° ìˆ«ìëŠ” {result}ì…ë‹ˆë‹¤");
    assert_eq!(*result, 100);

    let char_list = vec!['y', 'm', 'a', 'q'];

    let result = largest_char(&char_list);
    println!("ê°€ì¥ í° ë¬¸ìëŠ” {result}ì…ë‹ˆë‹¤");
    assert_eq!(*result, 'y');
}

largest_i32 í•¨ìˆ˜ëŠ” ëª©ë¡ 10-3ì—ì„œ ì¶”ì¶œí•œ ê²ƒìœ¼ë¡œ, ìŠ¬ë¼ì´ìŠ¤ì—ì„œ ê°€ì¥ í° i32ë¥¼ ì°¾ìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤. largest_char í•¨ìˆ˜ëŠ” ìŠ¬ë¼ì´ìŠ¤ì—ì„œ ê°€ì¥ í° charë¥¼ ì°¾ìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤. í•¨ìˆ˜ ë³¸ë¬¸ì€ ë™ì¼í•œ ì½”ë“œë¥¼ ê°€ì§€ë¯€ë¡œ, ë‹¨ì¼ í•¨ìˆ˜ì— ì œë„¤ë¦­ íƒ€ì… ë§¤ê°œë³€ìˆ˜ë¥¼ ë„ì…í•˜ì—¬ ì¤‘ë³µì„ ì œê±°í•´ ë´…ì‹œë‹¤.

To parameterize the types in a new single function, we need to name the type parameter, just as we do for the value parameters to a function. You can use any identifier as a type parameter name. But weâ€™ll use T because, by convention, type parameter names in Rust are short, often just one letter, and Rustâ€™s type-naming convention is UpperCamelCase. Short for type, T is the default choice of most Rust programmers.

When we use a parameter in the body of the function, we have to declare the parameter name in the signature so that the compiler knows what that name means. Similarly, when we use a type parameter name in a function signature, we have to declare the type parameter name before we use it. To define the generic largest function, we place type name declarations inside angle brackets, <>, between the name of the function and the parameter list, like this:

fn largest<T>(list: &[T]) -> &T {

We read this definition as â€œThe function largest is generic over some type T.â€ This function has one parameter named list, which is a slice of values of type T. The largest function will return a reference to a value of the same type T.

Listing 10-5 shows the combined largest function definition using the generic data type in its signature. The listing also shows how we can call the function with either a slice of i32 values or char values. Note that this code wonâ€™t compile yet.

fn largest<T>(list: &[T]) -> &T {
    let mut largest = &list[0];

    for item in list {
        if item > largest {
            largest = item;
        }
    }

    largest
}

fn main() {
    let number_list = vec![34, 50, 25, 100, 65];

    let result = largest(&number_list);
    println!("ê°€ì¥ í° ìˆ«ìëŠ” {result}ì…ë‹ˆë‹¤");

    let char_list = vec!['y', 'm', 'a', 'q'];

    let result = largest(&char_list);
    println!("ê°€ì¥ í° ë¬¸ìëŠ” {result}ì…ë‹ˆë‹¤");
}

ì´ ì½”ë“œë¥¼ ì§€ê¸ˆ ì»´íŒŒì¼í•˜ë©´ ë‹¤ìŒê³¼ ê°™ì€ ì˜¤ë¥˜ê°€ ë°œìƒí•  ê²ƒì…ë‹ˆë‹¤:

$ cargo run
   Compiling chapter10 v0.1.0 (file:///projects/chapter10)
error[E0369]: binary operation `>` cannot be applied to type `&T`
 --> src/main.rs:5:17
  |
5 |         if item > largest {
  |            ---- ^ ------- &T
  |            |
  |            &T
  |
help: consider restricting type parameter `T` with trait `PartialOrd`
  |
1 | fn largest<T: std::cmp::PartialOrd>(list: &[T]) -> &T {
  |             ++++++++++++++++++++++

For more information about this error, try `rustc --explain E0369`.
error: could not compile `chapter10` (bin "chapter10") due to 1 previous error

The help text mentions std::cmp::PartialOrd, which is a trait, and weâ€™re going to talk about traits in the next section. For now, know that this error states that the body of largest wonâ€™t work for all possible types that T could be. Because we want to compare values of type T in the body, we can only use types whose values can be ordered. To enable comparisons, the standard library has the std::cmp::PartialOrd trait that you can implement on types (see Appendix C for more on this trait). To fix Listing 10-5, we can follow the help textâ€™s suggestion and restrict the types valid for T to only those that implement PartialOrd. The listing will then compile, because the standard library implements PartialOrd on both i32 and char.

êµ¬ì¡°ì²´ ì •ì˜ì—ì„œ

ë˜í•œ <> êµ¬ë¬¸ì„ ì‚¬ìš©í•˜ì—¬ í•˜ë‚˜ ì´ìƒì˜ í•„ë“œì— ì œë„¤ë¦­ íƒ€ì… ë§¤ê°œë³€ìˆ˜ë¥¼ ì‚¬ìš©í•˜ë„ë¡ êµ¬ì¡°ì²´ë¥¼ ì •ì˜í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤. ëª©ë¡ 10-6ì€ ì–´ë–¤ íƒ€ì…ì˜ x ë° y ì¢Œí‘œ ê°’ì„ ì €ì¥í•˜ëŠ” Point<T> êµ¬ì¡°ì²´ë¥¼ ì •ì˜í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤.

struct Point<T> {
    x: T,
    y: T,
}

fn main() {
    let integer = Point { x: 5, y: 10 };
    let float = Point { x: 1.0, y: 4.0 };
}

The syntax for using generics in struct definitions is similar to that used in function definitions. First, we declare the name of the type parameter inside angle brackets just after the name of the struct. Then, we use the generic type in the struct definition where we would otherwise specify concrete data types.

ìš°ë¦¬ê°€ Point<T>ë¥¼ ì •ì˜í•˜ê¸° ìœ„í•´ í•˜ë‚˜ì˜ ì œë„¤ë¦­ íƒ€ì…ë§Œ ì‚¬ìš©í–ˆê¸° ë•Œë¬¸ì—, ì´ ì •ì˜ëŠ” Point<T> êµ¬ì¡°ì²´ê°€ ì–´ë–¤ íƒ€ì… Tì— ëŒ€í•´ ì œë„¤ë¦­ì´ë©°, xì™€ y í•„ë“œ ëª¨ë‘ ê·¸ ë™ì¼í•œ íƒ€ì…ì´ë¼ëŠ” ê²ƒì„ ì˜ë¯¸í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤. ê·¸ íƒ€ì…ì´ ë¬´ì—‡ì´ë“  ë§ì´ì£ . ë§Œì•½ ëª©ë¡ 10-7ê³¼ ê°™ì´ ë‹¤ë¥¸ íƒ€ì…ì˜ ê°’ì„ ê°€ì§„ Point<T> ì¸ìŠ¤í„´ìŠ¤ë¥¼ ìƒì„±í•˜ë©´, ìš°ë¦¬ ì½”ë“œëŠ” ì»´íŒŒì¼ë˜ì§€ ì•Šì„ ê²ƒì…ë‹ˆë‹¤.

struct Point<T> {
    x: T,
    y: T,
}

fn main() {
    let wont_work = Point { x: 5, y: 4.0 };
}

In this example, when we assign the integer value 5 to x, we let the compiler know that the generic type T will be an integer for this instance of Point<T>. Then, when we specify 4.0 for y, which weâ€™ve defined to have the same type as x, weâ€™ll get a type mismatch error like this:

$ cargo run
   Compiling chapter10 v0.1.0 (file:///projects/chapter10)
error[E0308]: mismatched types
 --> src/main.rs:7:38
  |
7 |     let wont_work = Point { x: 5, y: 4.0 };
  |                                      ^^^ expected integer, found floating-point number

For more information about this error, try `rustc --explain E0308`.
error: could not compile `chapter10` (bin "chapter10") due to 1 previous error

xì™€ yê°€ ëª¨ë‘ ì œë„¤ë¦­ì´ì§€ë§Œ ë‹¤ë¥¸ íƒ€ì…ì„ ê°€ì§ˆ ìˆ˜ ìˆëŠ” Point êµ¬ì¡°ì²´ë¥¼ ì •ì˜í•˜ë ¤ë©´, ì—¬ëŸ¬ ì œë„¤ë¦­ íƒ€ì… ë§¤ê°œë³€ìˆ˜ë¥¼ ì‚¬ìš©í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤. ì˜ˆë¥¼ ë“¤ì–´, ëª©ë¡ 10-8ì—ì„œëŠ” Pointì˜ ì •ì˜ë¥¼ xê°€ T íƒ€ì…ì´ê³  yê°€ U íƒ€ì…ì¸ Tì™€ U íƒ€ì…ì— ëŒ€í•´ ì œë„¤ë¦­ìœ¼ë¡œ ë³€ê²½í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤.

struct Point<T, U> {
    x: T,
    y: U,
}

fn main() {
    let both_integer = Point { x: 5, y: 10 };
    let both_float = Point { x: 1.0, y: 4.0 };
    let integer_and_float = Point { x: 5, y: 4.0 };
}

ì´ì œ í‘œì‹œëœ Pointì˜ ëª¨ë“  ì¸ìŠ¤í„´ìŠ¤ê°€ í—ˆìš©ë©ë‹ˆë‹¤! ì •ì˜ì—ì„œ ì›í•˜ëŠ” ë§Œí¼ ë§ì€ ì œë„¤ë¦­ íƒ€ì… ë§¤ê°œë³€ìˆ˜ë¥¼ ì‚¬ìš©í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆì§€ë§Œ, ëª‡ ê°œ ì´ìƒì„ ì‚¬ìš©í•˜ë©´ ì½”ë“œë¥¼ ì½ê¸° ì–´ë ¤ì›Œì§‘ë‹ˆë‹¤. ì½”ë“œì— ë§ì€ ì œë„¤ë¦­ íƒ€ì…ì´ í•„ìš”í•˜ë‹¤ê³  ìƒê°ë˜ë©´, ì½”ë“œë¥¼ ë” ì‘ì€ ì¡°ê°ìœ¼ë¡œ ì¬êµ¬ì„±í•´ì•¼ í•¨ì„ ë‚˜íƒ€ë‚¼ ìˆ˜ ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤.

ì—´ê±°í˜• ì •ì˜ì—ì„œ

êµ¬ì¡°ì²´ì—ì„œ í–ˆë˜ ê²ƒì²˜ëŸ¼, ì—´ê±°í˜•ì„ ì •ì˜í•˜ì—¬ variantì— ì œë„¤ë¦­ ë°ì´í„° íƒ€ì…ì„ ë‹´ì„ ìˆ˜ ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤. 6ì¥ì—ì„œ ì‚¬ìš©í–ˆë˜ í‘œì¤€ ë¼ì´ë¸ŒëŸ¬ë¦¬ê°€ ì œê³µí•˜ëŠ” Option<T> ì—´ê±°í˜•ì„ ë‹¤ì‹œ ì‚´í´ë³´ê² ìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤:

#![allow(unused)]
fn main() {
enum Option<T> {
    Some(T),
    None,
}
}

ì´ì œ ì´ ì •ì˜ê°€ ì—¬ëŸ¬ë¶„ì—ê²Œ ë” ì´í•´ê°€ ë  ê²ƒì…ë‹ˆë‹¤. ë³´ì‹œë‹¤ì‹œí”¼, Option<T> ì—´ê±°í˜•ì€ T íƒ€ì…ì— ëŒ€í•´ ì œë„¤ë¦­ì´ë©°, T íƒ€ì…ì˜ ê°’ í•˜ë‚˜ë¥¼ ë‹´ëŠ” Someê³¼ ì•„ë¬´ ê°’ë„ ë‹´ì§€ ì•ŠëŠ” Noneì´ë¼ëŠ” ë‘ ê°€ì§€ variantë¥¼ ê°€ì§‘ë‹ˆë‹¤. Option<T> ì—´ê±°í˜•ì„ ì‚¬ìš©í•¨ìœ¼ë¡œì¨ ì„ íƒì  ê°’ì´ë¼ëŠ” ì¶”ìƒì ì¸ ê°œë…ì„ í‘œí˜„í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆìœ¼ë©°, Option<T>ê°€ ì œë„¤ë¦­ì´ë¯€ë¡œ ì„ íƒì  ê°’ì˜ íƒ€ì…ì´ ë¬´ì—‡ì´ë“  ì´ ì¶”ìƒí™”ë¥¼ ì‚¬ìš©í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤.

ì—´ê±°í˜•ì€ ì—¬ëŸ¬ ì œë„¤ë¦­ íƒ€ì…ì„ ì‚¬ìš©í•  ìˆ˜ë„ ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤. 9ì¥ì—ì„œ ì‚¬ìš©í–ˆë˜ Result ì—´ê±°í˜•ì˜ ì •ì˜ê°€ í•œ ì˜ˆì…ë‹ˆë‹¤:

#![allow(unused)]
fn main() {
enum Result<T, E> {
    Ok(T),
    Err(E),
}
}

Result ì—´ê±°í˜•ì€ Tì™€ E ë‘ ê°€ì§€ íƒ€ì…ì— ëŒ€í•´ ì œë„¤ë¦­ì´ë©°, T íƒ€ì…ì˜ ê°’ì„ ë‹´ëŠ” Okì™€ E íƒ€ì…ì˜ ê°’ì„ ë‹´ëŠ” Err ë‘ ê°€ì§€ variantë¥¼ ê°€ì§‘ë‹ˆë‹¤. ì´ ì •ì˜ëŠ” ì„±ê³µí•  ìˆ˜ë„ ìˆê³  (T íƒ€ì…ì˜ ê°’ì„ ë°˜í™˜) ì‹¤íŒ¨í•  ìˆ˜ë„ ìˆëŠ” (E íƒ€ì…ì˜ ì˜¤ë¥˜ë¥¼ ë°˜í™˜) ì‘ì—…ì´ ìˆëŠ” ëª¨ë“  ê³³ì—ì„œ Result ì—´ê±°í˜•ì„ í¸ë¦¬í•˜ê²Œ ì‚¬ìš©í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆë„ë¡ í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤. ì‹¤ì œë¡œ ì´ê²ƒì€ ëª©ë¡ 9-3ì—ì„œ íŒŒì¼ì„ ì—´ ë•Œ ì‚¬ìš©í–ˆë˜ ê²ƒìœ¼ë¡œ, íŒŒì¼ì´ ì„±ê³µì ìœ¼ë¡œ ì—´ë ¸ì„ ë•Œ TëŠ” std::fs::File íƒ€ì…ìœ¼ë¡œ ì±„ì›Œì¡Œê³ , íŒŒì¼ì„ ì—¬ëŠ” ë° ë¬¸ì œê°€ ìˆì—ˆì„ ë•Œ EëŠ” std::io::Error íƒ€ì…ìœ¼ë¡œ ì±„ì›Œì¡ŒìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤.

ì½”ë“œì—ì„œ ê°’ì˜ íƒ€ì…ë§Œ ë‹¤ë¥¸ ì—¬ëŸ¬ êµ¬ì¡°ì²´ ë˜ëŠ” ì—´ê±°í˜• ì •ì˜ê°€ ìˆëŠ” ìƒí™©ì„ ì¸ì‹í•˜ë©´, ëŒ€ì‹  ì œë„¤ë¦­ íƒ€ì…ì„ ì‚¬ìš©í•˜ì—¬ ì¤‘ë³µì„ í”¼í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤.

ë©”ì„œë“œ ì •ì˜ì—ì„œ

êµ¬ì¡°ì²´ì™€ ì—´ê±°í˜•ì— ë©”ì„œë“œë¥¼ êµ¬í˜„í•˜ê³ (5ì¥ì—ì„œ í–ˆë˜ ê²ƒì²˜ëŸ¼) ì •ì˜ì— ì œë„¤ë¦­ íƒ€ì…ì„ ì‚¬ìš©í•  ìˆ˜ë„ ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤. ëª©ë¡ 10-9ëŠ” ëª©ë¡ 10-6ì—ì„œ ì •ì˜í•œ Point<T> êµ¬ì¡°ì²´ì— xë¼ëŠ” ë©”ì„œë“œê°€ êµ¬í˜„ëœ ê²ƒì„ ë³´ì—¬ì¤ë‹ˆë‹¤.

struct Point<T> {
    x: T,
    y: T,
}

impl<T> Point<T> {
    fn x(&self) -> &T {
        &self.x
    }
}

fn main() {
    let p = Point { x: 5, y: 10 };

    println!("p.x = {}", p.x());
}

ì—¬ê¸°ì„œ ìš°ë¦¬ëŠ” Point<T>ì— xë¼ëŠ” ë©”ì„œë“œë¥¼ ì •ì˜í–ˆìœ¼ë©°, ì´ ë©”ì„œë“œëŠ” í•„ë“œ xì˜ ë°ì´í„°ì— ëŒ€í•œ ì°¸ì¡°ë¥¼ ë°˜í™˜í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤.

Note that we have to declare T just after impl so that we can use T to specify that weâ€™re implementing methods on the type Point<T>. By declaring T as a generic type after impl, Rust can identify that the type in the angle brackets in Point is a generic type rather than a concrete type. We could have chosen a different name for this generic parameter than the generic parameter declared in the struct definition, but using the same name is conventional. If you write a method within an impl that declares a generic type, that method will be defined on any instance of the type, no matter what concrete type ends up substituting for the generic type.

We can also specify constraints on generic types when defining methods on the type. We could, for example, implement methods only on Point<f32> instances rather than on Point<T> instances with any generic type. In Listing 10-10, we use the concrete type f32, meaning we donâ€™t declare any types after impl.

struct Point<T> {
    x: T,
    y: T,
}

impl<T> Point<T> {
    fn x(&self) -> &T {
        &self.x
    }
}

impl Point<f32> {
    fn distance_from_origin(&self) -> f32 {
        (self.x.powi(2) + self.y.powi(2)).sqrt()
    }
}

fn main() {
    let p = Point { x: 5, y: 10 };

    println!("p.x = {}", p.x());
}

ì´ ì½”ë“œëŠ” Point<f32> íƒ€ì…ì´ distance_from_origin ë©”ì„œë“œë¥¼ ê°€ì§ˆ ê²ƒì„ì„ ì˜ë¯¸í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤. Tê°€ f32 íƒ€ì…ì´ ì•„ë‹Œ Point<T>ì˜ ë‹¤ë¥¸ ì¸ìŠ¤í„´ìŠ¤ì—ëŠ” ì´ ë©”ì„œë“œê°€ ì •ì˜ë˜ì§€ ì•ŠìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤. ì´ ë©”ì„œë“œëŠ” ìš°ë¦¬ ì ì´ ì¢Œí‘œ (0.0, 0.0)ì˜ ì ìœ¼ë¡œë¶€í„° ì–¼ë§ˆë‚˜ ë–¨ì–´ì ¸ ìˆëŠ”ì§€ ì¸¡ì •í•˜ë©°, ë¶€ë™ ì†Œìˆ˜ì  íƒ€ì…ì—ë§Œ ì‚¬ìš© ê°€ëŠ¥í•œ ìˆ˜í•™ ì—°ì‚°ì„ ì‚¬ìš©í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤.

Generic type parameters in a struct definition arenâ€™t always the same as those you use in that same structâ€™s method signatures. Listing 10-11 uses the generic types X1 and Y1 for the Point struct and X2 and Y2 for the mixup method signature to make the example clearer. The method creates a new Point instance with the x value from the self Point (of type X1) and the y value from the passed-in Point (of type Y2).

struct Point<X1, Y1> {
    x: X1,
    y: Y1,
}

impl<X1, Y1> Point<X1, Y1> {
    fn mixup<X2, Y2>(self, other: Point<X2, Y2>) -> Point<X1, Y2> {
        Point {
            x: self.x,
            y: other.y,
        }
    }
}

fn main() {
    let p1 = Point { x: 5, y: 10.4 };
    let p2 = Point { x: "Hello", y: 'c' };

    let p3 = p1.mixup(p2);

    println!("p3.x = {}, p3.y = {}", p3.x, p3.y);
}

mainì—ì„œ ìš°ë¦¬ëŠ” xì— i32 (ê°’ 5)ë¥¼, yì— f64 (ê°’ 10.4)ë¥¼ ê°€ì§„ Pointë¥¼ ì •ì˜í–ˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤. p2 ë³€ìˆ˜ëŠ” xì— ë¬¸ìì—´ ìŠ¬ë¼ì´ìŠ¤ (ê°’ "Hello")ë¥¼, yì— char (ê°’ c)ë¥¼ ê°€ì§„ Point êµ¬ì¡°ì²´ì…ë‹ˆë‹¤. p1ì— p2 ì¸ìˆ˜ë¥¼ ì‚¬ìš©í•˜ì—¬ mixupì„ í˜¸ì¶œí•˜ë©´ p3ë¥¼ ì–»ê²Œ ë˜ëŠ”ë°, xëŠ” p1ì—ì„œ ì™”ìœ¼ë¯€ë¡œ p3ëŠ” xì— i32ë¥¼ ê°€ì§ˆ ê²ƒì…ë‹ˆë‹¤. p3 ë³€ìˆ˜ëŠ” yì— charë¥¼ ê°€ì§ˆ ê²ƒì¸ë°, yëŠ” p2ì—ì„œ ì™”ê¸° ë•Œë¬¸ì…ë‹ˆë‹¤. println! ë§¤í¬ë¡œ í˜¸ì¶œì€ p3.x = 5, p3.y = cë¥¼ ì¶œë ¥í•  ê²ƒì…ë‹ˆë‹¤.

ì´ ì˜ˆì œì˜ ëª©ì ì€ ì¼ë¶€ ì œë„¤ë¦­ ë§¤ê°œë³€ìˆ˜ê°€ implë¡œ ì„ ì–¸ë˜ê³  ì¼ë¶€ëŠ” ë©”ì„œë“œ ì •ì˜ë¡œ ì„ ì–¸ë˜ëŠ” ìƒí™©ì„ ë³´ì—¬ì£¼ëŠ” ê²ƒì…ë‹ˆë‹¤. ì—¬ê¸°ì„œ ì œë„¤ë¦­ ë§¤ê°œë³€ìˆ˜ X1ê³¼ Y1ì€ êµ¬ì¡°ì²´ ì •ì˜ì™€ í•¨ê»˜ ì‚¬ìš©ë˜ë¯€ë¡œ impl ë’¤ì— ì„ ì–¸ë©ë‹ˆë‹¤. ì œë„¤ë¦­ ë§¤ê°œë³€ìˆ˜ X2ì™€ Y2ëŠ” ë©”ì„œë“œì—ë§Œ ê´€ë ¨ë˜ë¯€ë¡œ fn mixup ë’¤ì— ì„ ì–¸ë©ë‹ˆë‹¤.

ì œë„¤ë¦­ì„ ì‚¬ìš©í•˜ëŠ” ì½”ë“œì˜ ì„±ëŠ¥

ì œë„¤ë¦­ íƒ€ì… ë§¤ê°œë³€ìˆ˜ë¥¼ ì‚¬ìš©í•  ë•Œ ëŸ°íƒ€ì„ ë¹„ìš©ì´ ë°œìƒí•˜ëŠ”ì§€ ê¶ê¸ˆí•  ìˆ˜ ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤. ì¢‹ì€ ì†Œì‹ì€ ì œë„¤ë¦­ íƒ€ì…ì„ ì‚¬ìš©í•´ë„ êµ¬ì²´ì ì¸ íƒ€ì…ì„ ì‚¬ìš©í•  ë•Œë³´ë‹¤ í”„ë¡œê·¸ë¨ ì‹¤í–‰ ì†ë„ê°€ ëŠë ¤ì§€ì§€ ì•ŠëŠ”ë‹¤ëŠ” ê²ƒì…ë‹ˆë‹¤.

Rust accomplishes this by performing monomorphization of the code using generics at compile time. Monomorphization is the process of turning generic code into specific code by filling in the concrete types that are used when compiled. In this process, the compiler does the opposite of the steps we used to create the generic function in Listing 10-5: The compiler looks at all the places where generic code is called and generates code for the concrete types the generic code is called with.

í‘œì¤€ ë¼ì´ë¸ŒëŸ¬ë¦¬ì˜ ì œë„¤ë¦­ Option<T> ì—´ê±°í˜•ì„ ì‚¬ìš©í•˜ì—¬ ì´ê²ƒì´ ì–´ë–»ê²Œ ì‘ë™í•˜ëŠ”ì§€ ì‚´í´ë³´ê² ìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤:

#![allow(unused)]
fn main() {
let integer = Some(5);
let float = Some(5.0);
}

When Rust compiles this code, it performs monomorphization. During that process, the compiler reads the values that have been used in Option<T> instances and identifies two kinds of Option<T>: One is i32 and the other is f64. As such, it expands the generic definition of Option<T> into two definitions specialized to i32 and f64, thereby replacing the generic definition with the specific ones.

ë‹¨í˜•ì„±ëœ ì½”ë“œ ë²„ì „ì€ ë‹¤ìŒ(ì»´íŒŒì¼ëŸ¬ëŠ” ì—¬ê¸°ì—ì„œ ì„¤ëª… ëª©ì ìœ¼ë¡œ ì‚¬ìš©í•˜ëŠ” ì´ë¦„ê³¼ ë‹¤ë¥¸ ì´ë¦„ì„ ì‚¬ìš©í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤)ê³¼ ìœ ì‚¬í•˜ê²Œ ë³´ì…ë‹ˆë‹¤:

enum Option_i32 {
    Some(i32),
    None,
}

enum Option_f64 {
    Some(f64),
    None,
}

fn main() {
    let integer = Option_i32::Some(5);
    let float = Option_f64::Some(5.0);
}

ì œë„¤ë¦­ Option<T>ëŠ” ì»´íŒŒì¼ëŸ¬ê°€ ìƒì„±í•œ íŠ¹ì • ì •ì˜ë¡œ ëŒ€ì²´ë©ë‹ˆë‹¤. ëŸ¬ìŠ¤íŠ¸ëŠ” ì œë„¤ë¦­ ì½”ë“œë¥¼ ê° ì¸ìŠ¤í„´ìŠ¤ì—ì„œ íƒ€ì…ì„ ì§€ì •í•˜ëŠ” ì½”ë“œë¡œ ì»´íŒŒì¼í•˜ê¸° ë•Œë¬¸ì—, ì œë„¤ë¦­ì„ ì‚¬ìš©í•´ë„ ëŸ°íƒ€ì„ ë¹„ìš©ì´ ë°œìƒí•˜ì§€ ì•ŠìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤. ì½”ë“œê°€ ì‹¤í–‰ë  ë•Œ, ê° ì •ì˜ë¥¼ ìˆ˜ë™ìœ¼ë¡œ ë³µì œí•œ ê²ƒê³¼ ë™ì¼í•˜ê²Œ ì‘ë™í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤. ë‹¨í˜•ì„±(monomorphization) ê³¼ì •ì€ ëŸ¬ìŠ¤íŠ¸ì˜ ì œë„¤ë¦­ì„ ëŸ°íƒ€ì„ì— ë§¤ìš° íš¨ìœ¨ì ìœ¼ë¡œ ë§Œë“­ë‹ˆë‹¤.

Defining Shared Behavior with Traits

_íŠ¸ë ˆì´íŠ¸_ëŠ” íŠ¹ì • íƒ€ì…ì´ ê°€ì§€ëŠ” ê¸°ëŠ¥ê³¼ ë‹¤ë¥¸ íƒ€ì…ê³¼ ê³µìœ í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆëŠ” ê¸°ëŠ¥ì„ ì •ì˜í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤. íŠ¸ë ˆì´íŠ¸ë¥¼ ì‚¬ìš©í•˜ì—¬ ê³µìœ ëœ ë™ì‘ì„ ì¶”ìƒì ì¸ ë°©ì‹ìœ¼ë¡œ ì •ì˜í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤. _íŠ¸ë ˆì´íŠ¸ ë°”ìš´ë“œ_ë¥¼ ì‚¬ìš©í•˜ì—¬ ì œë„¤ë¦­ íƒ€ì…ì´ íŠ¹ì • ë™ì‘ì„ ê°€ì§„ ì–´ë–¤ íƒ€ì…ì´ë“  ë  ìˆ˜ ìˆìŒì„ ì§€ì •í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤.

ì°¸ê³ : íŠ¸ë ˆì´íŠ¸ëŠ” ë‹¤ë¥¸ ì–¸ì–´ì—ì„œ ì¢…ì¢… _ì¸í„°í˜ì´ìŠ¤_ë¼ê³  ë¶ˆë¦¬ëŠ” ê¸°ëŠ¥ê³¼ ìœ ì‚¬í•˜ì§€ë§Œ, ëª‡ ê°€ì§€ ì°¨ì´ì ì´ ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤.

íŠ¸ë ˆì´íŠ¸ ì •ì˜í•˜ê¸°

íƒ€ì…ì˜ ë™ì‘ì€ í•´ë‹¹ íƒ€ì…ì—ì„œ í˜¸ì¶œí•  ìˆ˜ ìˆëŠ” ë©”ì„œë“œë¡œ êµ¬ì„±ë©ë‹ˆë‹¤. ëª¨ë“  íƒ€ì…ì—ì„œ ë™ì¼í•œ ë©”ì„œë“œë¥¼ í˜¸ì¶œí•  ìˆ˜ ìˆë‹¤ë©´ ë‹¤ë¥¸ íƒ€ì…ë“¤ë„ ë™ì¼í•œ ë™ì‘ì„ ê³µìœ í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤. íŠ¸ë ˆì´íŠ¸ ì •ì˜ëŠ” íŠ¹ì • ëª©ì ì„ ë‹¬ì„±í•˜ëŠ” ë° í•„ìš”í•œ ì¼ë ¨ì˜ ë™ì‘ì„ ì •ì˜í•˜ê¸° ìœ„í•´ ë©”ì„œë“œ ì‹œê·¸ë‹ˆì²˜ë¥¼ í•¨ê»˜ ê·¸ë£¹í™”í•˜ëŠ” ë°©ë²•ì…ë‹ˆë‹¤.

For example, letâ€™s say we have multiple structs that hold various kinds and amounts of text: a NewsArticle struct that holds a news story filed in a particular location and a SocialPost that can have, at most, 280 characters along with metadata that indicates whether it was a new post, a repost, or a reply to another post.

We want to make a media aggregator library crate named aggregator that can display summaries of data that might be stored in a NewsArticle or SocialPost instance. To do this, we need a summary from each type, and weâ€™ll request that summary by calling a summarize method on an instance. Listing 10-12 shows the definition of a public Summary trait that expresses this behavior.

pub trait Summary {
    fn summarize(&self) -> String;
}

ì—¬ê¸°ì„œ ìš°ë¦¬ëŠ” trait í‚¤ì›Œë“œì™€ íŠ¸ë ˆì´íŠ¸ ì´ë¦„(ì´ ê²½ìš° Summary)ì„ ì‚¬ìš©í•˜ì—¬ íŠ¸ë ˆì´íŠ¸ë¥¼ ì„ ì–¸í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤. ë˜í•œ ì´ íŠ¸ë ˆì´íŠ¸ë¥¼ pubìœ¼ë¡œ ì„ ì–¸í•˜ì—¬ ì´ í¬ë ˆì´íŠ¸ì— ì˜ì¡´í•˜ëŠ” í¬ë ˆì´íŠ¸ë„ ì´ íŠ¸ë ˆì´íŠ¸ë¥¼ ì‚¬ìš©í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆë„ë¡ í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤. ëª‡ ê°€ì§€ ì˜ˆì œì—ì„œ ì´ë¥¼ í™•ì¸í•  ê²ƒì…ë‹ˆë‹¤. ì¤‘ê´„í˜¸ ì•ˆì—ëŠ” ì´ íŠ¸ë ˆì´íŠ¸ë¥¼ êµ¬í˜„í•˜ëŠ” íƒ€ì…ì˜ ë™ì‘ì„ ì„¤ëª…í•˜ëŠ” ë©”ì„œë“œ ì‹œê·¸ë‹ˆì²˜ë¥¼ ì„ ì–¸í•˜ë©°, ì´ ê²½ìš° fn summarize(&self) -> Stringì…ë‹ˆë‹¤.

ë©”ì„œë“œ ì‹œê·¸ë‹ˆì²˜ ë’¤ì—ëŠ” ì¤‘ê´„í˜¸ ì•ˆì— êµ¬í˜„ì„ ì œê³µí•˜ëŠ” ëŒ€ì‹  ì„¸ë¯¸ì½œë¡ ì„ ì‚¬ìš©í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤. ì´ íŠ¸ë ˆì´íŠ¸ë¥¼ êµ¬í˜„í•˜ëŠ” ê° íƒ€ì…ì€ ë©”ì„œë“œ ë³¸ë¬¸ì— ëŒ€í•´ ìì²´ì ì¸ ì‚¬ìš©ì ì •ì˜ ë™ì‘ì„ ì œê³µí•´ì•¼ í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤. ì»´íŒŒì¼ëŸ¬ëŠ” Summary íŠ¸ë ˆì´íŠ¸ë¥¼ ê°€ì§„ ëª¨ë“  íƒ€ì…ì´ ì´ ì‹œê·¸ë‹ˆì²˜ì™€ ì •í™•íˆ ì¼ì¹˜í•˜ëŠ” summarize ë©”ì„œë“œë¥¼ ì •ì˜í•˜ë„ë¡ ê°•ì œí•  ê²ƒì…ë‹ˆë‹¤.

A trait can have multiple methods in its body: The method signatures are listed one per line, and each line ends in a semicolon.

íƒ€ì…ì— íŠ¸ë ˆì´íŠ¸ êµ¬í˜„í•˜ê¸°

Now that weâ€™ve defined the desired signatures of the Summary traitâ€™s methods, we can implement it on the types in our media aggregator. Listing 10-13 shows an implementation of the Summary trait on the NewsArticle struct that uses the headline, the author, and the location to create the return value of summarize. For the SocialPost struct, we define summarize as the username followed by the entire text of the post, assuming that the post content is already limited to 280 characters.

pub trait Summary {
    fn summarize(&self) -> String;
}

pub struct NewsArticle {
    pub headline: String,
    pub location: String,
    pub author: String,
    pub content: String,
}

impl Summary for NewsArticle {
    fn summarize(&self) -> String {
        format!("{}, {} ì‘ì„± ({})", self.headline, self.author, self.location)
    }
}

pub struct SocialPost {
    pub username: String,
    pub content: String,
    pub reply: bool,
    pub repost: bool,
}

impl Summary for SocialPost {
    fn summarize(&self) -> String {
        format!("{}: {}", self.username, self.content)
    }
}

íƒ€ì…ì— íŠ¸ë ˆì´íŠ¸ë¥¼ êµ¬í˜„í•˜ëŠ” ê²ƒì€ ì¼ë°˜ ë©”ì„œë“œë¥¼ êµ¬í˜„í•˜ëŠ” ê²ƒê³¼ ìœ ì‚¬í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤. ì°¨ì´ì ì€ impl ë‹¤ìŒì— êµ¬í˜„í•˜ë ¤ëŠ” íŠ¸ë ˆì´íŠ¸ ì´ë¦„ì„ ë„£ê³ , ê·¸ ë‹¤ìŒ for í‚¤ì›Œë“œë¥¼ ì‚¬ìš©í•œ ë‹¤ìŒ, íŠ¸ë ˆì´íŠ¸ë¥¼ êµ¬í˜„í•˜ë ¤ëŠ” íƒ€ì…ì˜ ì´ë¦„ì„ ì§€ì •í•œë‹¤ëŠ” ê²ƒì…ë‹ˆë‹¤. impl ë¸”ë¡ ë‚´ì—ëŠ” íŠ¸ë ˆì´íŠ¸ ì •ì˜ê°€ ì •ì˜í•œ ë©”ì„œë“œ ì‹œê·¸ë‹ˆì²˜ë¥¼ ë„£ìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤. ê° ì‹œê·¸ë‹ˆì²˜ ë’¤ì— ì„¸ë¯¸ì½œë¡ ì„ ì¶”ê°€í•˜ëŠ” ëŒ€ì‹  ì¤‘ê´„í˜¸ë¥¼ ì‚¬ìš©í•˜ê³  í•´ë‹¹ íƒ€ì…ì— ëŒ€í•´ íŠ¸ë ˆì´íŠ¸ì˜ ë©”ì„œë“œê°€ ê°€ì ¸ì•¼ í•  íŠ¹ì • ë™ì‘ìœ¼ë¡œ ë©”ì„œë“œ ë³¸ë¬¸ì„ ì±„ì›ë‹ˆë‹¤.

Now that the library has implemented the Summary trait on NewsArticle and SocialPost, users of the crate can call the trait methods on instances of NewsArticle and SocialPost in the same way we call regular methods. The only difference is that the user must bring the trait into scope as well as the types. Hereâ€™s an example of how a binary crate could use our aggregator library crate:

use aggregator::{SocialPost, Summary};

fn main() {
    let post = SocialPost {
        username: String::from("horse_ebooks"),
        content: String::from(
            "ë¬¼ë¡ , ì´ë¯¸ ì•Œê³  ê³„ì‹œê² ì§€ë§Œ, ì‚¬ëŒë“¤",
        ),
        reply: false,
        repost: false,
    };

    println!("1 new post: {}", post.summarize());
}

This code prints 1 new post: horse_ebooks: of course, as you probably already know, people.

Other crates that depend on the aggregator crate can also bring the Summary trait into scope to implement Summary on their own types. One restriction to note is that we can implement a trait on a type only if either the trait or the type, or both, are local to our crate. For example, we can implement standard library traits like Display on a custom type like SocialPost as part of our aggregator crate functionality because the type SocialPost is local to our aggregator crate. We can also implement Summary on Vec<T> in our aggregator crate because the trait Summary is local to our aggregator crate.

But we canâ€™t implement external traits on external types. For example, we canâ€™t implement the Display trait on Vec<T> within our aggregator crate, because Display and Vec<T> are both defined in the standard library and arenâ€™t local to our aggregator crate. This restriction is part of a property called coherence, and more specifically the orphan rule, so named because the parent type is not present. This rule ensures that other peopleâ€™s code canâ€™t break your code and vice versa. Without the rule, two crates could implement the same trait for the same type, and Rust wouldnâ€™t know which implementation to use.

Using Default Implementations

ë•Œë¡œëŠ” ëª¨ë“  íƒ€ì…ì—ì„œ ëª¨ë“  ë©”ì„œë“œë¥¼ êµ¬í˜„í•˜ë„ë¡ ìš”êµ¬í•˜ëŠ” ëŒ€ì‹  íŠ¸ë ˆì´íŠ¸ì˜ ì¼ë¶€ ë˜ëŠ” ëª¨ë“  ë©”ì„œë“œì— ëŒ€í•´ ê¸°ë³¸ ë™ì‘ì„ ê°–ëŠ” ê²ƒì´ ìœ ìš©í•  ë•Œê°€ ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤. ê·¸ëŸ¬ë©´ íŠ¹ì • íƒ€ì…ì— íŠ¸ë ˆì´íŠ¸ë¥¼ êµ¬í˜„í•  ë•Œ ê° ë©”ì„œë“œì˜ ê¸°ë³¸ ë™ì‘ì„ ìœ ì§€í•˜ê±°ë‚˜ ì¬ì •ì˜í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤.

ëª©ë¡ 10-14ì—ì„œëŠ” ëª©ë¡ 10-12ì—ì„œ í–ˆë˜ ê²ƒì²˜ëŸ¼ ë©”ì„œë“œ ì‹œê·¸ë‹ˆì²˜ë§Œ ì •ì˜í•˜ëŠ” ëŒ€ì‹ , Summary íŠ¸ë ˆì´íŠ¸ì˜ summarize ë©”ì„œë“œì— ëŒ€í•œ ê¸°ë³¸ ë¬¸ìì—´ì„ ì§€ì •í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤.

pub trait Summary {
    fn summarize(&self) -> String {
        String::from("(ë” ì½ì–´ë³´ê¸°...)")
    }
}

pub struct NewsArticle {
    pub headline: String,
    pub location: String,
    pub author: String,
    pub content: String,
}

impl Summary for NewsArticle {}

pub struct SocialPost {
    pub username: String,
    pub content: String,
    pub reply: bool,
    pub repost: bool,
}

impl Summary for SocialPost {
    fn summarize(&self) -> String {
        format!("{}: {}", self.username, self.content)
    }
}

NewsArticle ì¸ìŠ¤í„´ìŠ¤ë¥¼ ìš”ì•½í•˜ê¸° ìœ„í•´ ê¸°ë³¸ êµ¬í˜„ì„ ì‚¬ìš©í•˜ë ¤ë©´, impl Summary for NewsArticle {}ê³¼ ê°™ì´ ë¹ˆ impl ë¸”ë¡ì„ ì§€ì •í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤.

NewsArticleì— summarize ë©”ì„œë“œë¥¼ ì§ì ‘ ì •ì˜í•˜ì§€ëŠ” ì•Šì•˜ì§€ë§Œ, ê¸°ë³¸ êµ¬í˜„ì„ ì œê³µí•˜ê³  NewsArticleì´ Summary íŠ¸ë ˆì´íŠ¸ë¥¼ êµ¬í˜„í•œë‹¤ê³  ì§€ì •í–ˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤. ê²°ê³¼ì ìœ¼ë¡œ ë‹¤ìŒê³¼ ê°™ì´ NewsArticleì˜ ì¸ìŠ¤í„´ìŠ¤ì—ì„œ summarize ë©”ì„œë“œë¥¼ í˜¸ì¶œí•  ìˆ˜ ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤:

use aggregator::{self, NewsArticle, Summary};

fn main() {
    let article = NewsArticle {
        headline: String::from("í­ê·„ìŠ¤, ìŠ¤íƒ ë¦¬ ì»µ ì±”í”¼ì–¸ì‹­ ìš°ìŠ¹!"),
        location: String::from("ë¯¸êµ­ íœì‹¤ë² ì´ë‹ˆì•„ì£¼ í”¼ì¸ ë²„ê·¸"),
        author: String::from("ì•„ì´ìŠ¤ë²„ê·¸"),
        content: String::from(
            "í”¼ì¸ ë²„ê·¸ í­ê·„ìŠ¤ëŠ” ë‹¤ì‹œ í•œë²ˆ NHL ìµœê³ ì˜ \
             í•˜í‚¤ íŒ€ì´ ë˜ì—ˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤.",
        ),
    };

    println!("ìƒˆë¡œìš´ ê¸°ì‚¬ë¥¼ ë³¼ ìˆ˜ ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤! {}", article.summarize());
}

ì´ ì½”ë“œëŠ” ìƒˆë¡œìš´ ê¸°ì‚¬ë¥¼ ë³¼ ìˆ˜ ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤! (ë” ì½ì–´ë³´ê¸°...)ë¥¼ ì¶œë ¥í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤.

Creating a default implementation doesnâ€™t require us to change anything about the implementation of Summary on SocialPost in Listing 10-13. The reason is that the syntax for overriding a default implementation is the same as the syntax for implementing a trait method that doesnâ€™t have a default implementation.

ê¸°ë³¸ êµ¬í˜„ì€ ë™ì¼í•œ íŠ¸ë ˆì´íŠ¸ ë‚´ì˜ ë‹¤ë¥¸ ë©”ì„œë“œë¥¼ í˜¸ì¶œí•  ìˆ˜ ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤. ê·¸ ë‹¤ë¥¸ ë©”ì„œë“œì— ê¸°ë³¸ êµ¬í˜„ì´ ì—†ë”ë¼ë„ ìƒê´€ì—†ìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤. ì´ëŸ° ë°©ì‹ìœ¼ë¡œ íŠ¸ë ˆì´íŠ¸ëŠ” ë§ì€ ìœ ìš©í•œ ê¸°ëŠ¥ì„ ì œê³µí•˜ë©´ì„œ êµ¬í˜„ìê°€ ê·¸ ì¤‘ ì¼ë¶€ë§Œ ì§€ì •í•˜ë„ë¡ ìš”êµ¬í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤. ì˜ˆë¥¼ ë“¤ì–´, Summary íŠ¸ë ˆì´íŠ¸ì— êµ¬í˜„ì´ í•„ìš”í•œ summarize_author ë©”ì„œë“œë¥¼ ì •ì˜í•˜ê³ , summarize ë©”ì„œë“œëŠ” summarize_author ë©”ì„œë“œë¥¼ í˜¸ì¶œí•˜ëŠ” ê¸°ë³¸ êµ¬í˜„ì„ ê°–ë„ë¡ ì •ì˜í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤:

pub trait Summary {
    fn summarize_author(&self) -> String;

    fn summarize(&self) -> String {
        format!("(...{}ì—ì„œ ë” ì½ì–´ë³´ê¸°)", self.summarize_author())
    }
}

pub struct SocialPost {
    pub username: String,
    pub content: String,
    pub reply: bool,
    pub repost: bool,
}

impl Summary for SocialPost {
    fn summarize_author(&self) -> String {
        format!("@{}", self.username)
    }
}

ì´ Summary ë²„ì „ì„ ì‚¬ìš©í•˜ë ¤ë©´, íƒ€ì…ì— íŠ¸ë ˆì´íŠ¸ë¥¼ êµ¬í˜„í•  ë•Œ summarize_authorë§Œ ì •ì˜í•˜ë©´ ë©ë‹ˆë‹¤:

pub trait Summary {
    fn summarize_author(&self) -> String;

    fn summarize(&self) -> String {
        format!("(...{}ì—ì„œ ë” ì½ì–´ë³´ê¸°)", self.summarize_author())
    }
}

pub struct SocialPost {
    pub username: String,
    pub content: String,
    pub reply: bool,
    pub repost: bool,
}

impl Summary for SocialPost {
    fn summarize_author(&self) -> String {
        format!("@{}", self.username)
    }
}

After we define summarize_author, we can call summarize on instances of the SocialPost struct, and the default implementation of summarize will call the definition of summarize_author that weâ€™ve provided. Because weâ€™ve implemented summarize_author, the Summary trait has given us the behavior of the summarize method without requiring us to write any more code. Hereâ€™s what that looks like:

use aggregator::{self, SocialPost, Summary};

fn main() {
    let post = SocialPost {
        username: String::from("horse_ebooks"),
        content: String::from(
            "ë¬¼ë¡ , ì´ë¯¸ ì•Œê³  ê³„ì‹œê² ì§€ë§Œ, ì‚¬ëŒë“¤",
        ),
        reply: false,
        repost: false,
    };

    println!("1 new post: {}", post.summarize());
}

This code prints 1 new post: (Read more from @horse_ebooks...).

ë™ì¼í•œ ë©”ì„œë“œë¥¼ ì¬ì •ì˜í•˜ëŠ” êµ¬í˜„ì—ì„œëŠ” ê¸°ë³¸ êµ¬í˜„ì„ í˜¸ì¶œí•  ìˆ˜ ì—†ë‹¤ëŠ” ì ì— ìœ ì˜í•˜ì„¸ìš”.

Using Traits as Parameters

Now that you know how to define and implement traits, we can explore how to use traits to define functions that accept many different types. Weâ€™ll use the Summary trait we implemented on the NewsArticle and SocialPost types in Listing 10-13 to define a notify function that calls the summarize method on its item parameter, which is of some type that implements the Summary trait. To do this, we use the impl Trait syntax, like this:

pub trait Summary {
    fn summarize(&self) -> String;
}

pub struct NewsArticle {
    pub headline: String,
    pub location: String,
    pub author: String,
    pub content: String,
}

impl Summary for NewsArticle {
    fn summarize(&self) -> String {
        format!("{}, {} ì‘ì„± ({})", self.headline, self.author, self.location)
    }
}

pub struct SocialPost {
    pub username: String,
    pub content: String,
    pub reply: bool,
    pub repost: bool,
}

impl Summary for SocialPost {
    fn summarize(&self) -> String {
        format!("{}: {}", self.username, self.content)
    }
}

pub fn notify(item: &impl Summary) {
    println!("ì†ë³´! {}", item.summarize());
}

Instead of a concrete type for the item parameter, we specify the impl keyword and the trait name. This parameter accepts any type that implements the specified trait. In the body of notify, we can call any methods on item that come from the Summary trait, such as summarize. We can call notify and pass in any instance of NewsArticle or SocialPost. Code that calls the function with any other type, such as a String or an i32, wonâ€™t compile, because those types donâ€™t implement Summary.

íŠ¸ë ˆì´íŠ¸ ë°”ìš´ë“œ ë¬¸ë²•

impl Trait ë¬¸ë²•ì€ ê°„ë‹¨í•œ ê²½ìš°ì—ëŠ” ì˜ ì‘ë™í•˜ì§€ë§Œ, ì‹¤ì œë¡œëŠ” _íŠ¸ë ˆì´íŠ¸ ë°”ìš´ë“œ_ë¼ê³  ì•Œë ¤ì§„ ë” ê¸´ í˜•íƒœì— ëŒ€í•œ ë¬¸ë²•ì  ì„¤íƒ•(syntax sugar)ì…ë‹ˆë‹¤. ë‹¤ìŒê³¼ ê°™ì´ ìƒê²¼ìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤:

pub fn notify<T: Summary>(item: &T) {
    println!("ì†ë³´! {}", item.summarize());
}

ì´ ë” ê¸´ í˜•íƒœëŠ” ì´ì „ ì„¹ì…˜ì˜ ì˜ˆì œì™€ ë™ì¼í•˜ì§€ë§Œ ë” ì¥í™©í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤. ì œë„¤ë¦­ íƒ€ì… ë§¤ê°œë³€ìˆ˜ ì„ ì–¸ê³¼ í•¨ê»˜ ì½œë¡  ë’¤ì—, ê·¸ë¦¬ê³  êº¾ì‡  ê´„í˜¸ ì•ˆì— íŠ¸ë ˆì´íŠ¸ ë°”ìš´ë“œë¥¼ ë°°ì¹˜í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤.

impl Trait ë¬¸ë²•ì€ í¸ë¦¬í•˜ê³  ê°„ë‹¨í•œ ê²½ìš°ì— ì½”ë“œë¥¼ ë” ê°„ê²°í•˜ê²Œ ë§Œë“¤ì§€ë§Œ, ë” ì™„ì „í•œ íŠ¸ë ˆì´íŠ¸ ë°”ìš´ë“œ ë¬¸ë²•ì€ ë‹¤ë¥¸ ê²½ìš°ì— ë” ë§ì€ ë³µì¡ì„±ì„ í‘œí˜„í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤. ì˜ˆë¥¼ ë“¤ì–´, Summaryë¥¼ êµ¬í˜„í•˜ëŠ” ë‘ ê°œì˜ ë§¤ê°œë³€ìˆ˜ë¥¼ ê°€ì§ˆ ìˆ˜ ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤. impl Trait ë¬¸ë²•ìœ¼ë¡œ ê·¸ë ‡ê²Œ í•˜ë©´ ë‹¤ìŒê³¼ ê°™ìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤:

pub fn notify(item1: &impl Summary, item2: &impl Summary) {

impl Traitì„ ì‚¬ìš©í•˜ëŠ” ê²ƒì€ item1ê³¼ item2ê°€ ë‹¤ë¥¸ íƒ€ì…ì„ ê°–ë„ë¡ í—ˆìš©í•˜ë ¤ëŠ” ê²½ìš°(ë‘ íƒ€ì… ëª¨ë‘ Summaryë¥¼ êµ¬í˜„í•˜ëŠ” í•œ)ì— ì ì ˆí•©ë‹ˆë‹¤. í•˜ì§€ë§Œ ë‘ ë§¤ê°œë³€ìˆ˜ê°€ ë™ì¼í•œ íƒ€ì…ì„ ê°–ë„ë¡ ê°•ì œí•˜ë ¤ë©´ ë‹¤ìŒê³¼ ê°™ì´ íŠ¸ë ˆì´íŠ¸ ë°”ìš´ë“œë¥¼ ì‚¬ìš©í•´ì•¼ í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤:

pub fn notify<T: Summary>(item1: &T, item2: &T) {

item1ê³¼ item2 ë§¤ê°œë³€ìˆ˜ì˜ íƒ€ì…ìœ¼ë¡œ ì§€ì •ëœ ì œë„¤ë¦­ íƒ€ì… TëŠ” item1ê³¼ item2ì— ëŒ€í•œ ì¸ìˆ˜ë¡œ ì „ë‹¬ë˜ëŠ” ê°’ì˜ êµ¬ì²´ì ì¸ íƒ€ì…ì´ ë™ì¼í•´ì•¼ í•˜ë„ë¡ í•¨ìˆ˜ë¥¼ ì œì•½í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤.

Multiple Trait Bounds with the + Syntax

We can also specify more than one trait bound. Say we wanted notify to use display formatting as well as summarize on item: We specify in the notify definition that item must implement both Display and Summary. We can do so using the + syntax:

pub fn notify(item: &(impl Summary + Display)) {

+ ë¬¸ë²•ì€ ì œë„¤ë¦­ íƒ€ì…ì˜ íŠ¸ë ˆì´íŠ¸ ë°”ìš´ë“œì—ì„œë„ ìœ íš¨í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤:

pub fn notify<T: Summary + Display>(item: &T) {

ë‘ ê°œì˜ íŠ¸ë ˆì´íŠ¸ ë°”ìš´ë“œê°€ ì§€ì •ë˜ì—ˆìœ¼ë¯€ë¡œ notifyì˜ ë³¸ë¬¸ì€ summarizeë¥¼ í˜¸ì¶œí•˜ê³  {}ë¥¼ ì‚¬ìš©í•˜ì—¬ itemì„ í¬ë§·íŒ…í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤.

where ì ˆë¡œ íŠ¸ë ˆì´íŠ¸ ë°”ìš´ë“œë¥¼ ë” ëª…í™•í•˜ê²Œ í•˜ê¸°

ë„ˆë¬´ ë§ì€ íŠ¸ë ˆì´íŠ¸ ë°”ìš´ë“œë¥¼ ì‚¬ìš©í•˜ëŠ” ê²ƒì—ëŠ” ë‹¨ì ì´ ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤. ê° ì œë„¤ë¦­ì—ëŠ” ê³ ìœ í•œ íŠ¸ë ˆì´íŠ¸ ë°”ìš´ë“œê°€ ìˆìœ¼ë¯€ë¡œ, ì—¬ëŸ¬ ì œë„¤ë¦­ íƒ€ì… ë§¤ê°œë³€ìˆ˜ë¥¼ ê°€ì§„ í•¨ìˆ˜ëŠ” í•¨ìˆ˜ ì´ë¦„ê³¼ ë§¤ê°œë³€ìˆ˜ ëª©ë¡ ì‚¬ì´ì— ë§ì€ íŠ¸ë ˆì´íŠ¸ ë°”ìš´ë“œ ì •ë³´ë¥¼ í¬í•¨í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆì–´ í•¨ìˆ˜ ì‹œê·¸ë‹ˆì²˜ë¥¼ ì½ê¸° ì–´ë µê²Œ ë§Œë“­ë‹ˆë‹¤. ì´ëŸ¬í•œ ì´ìœ ë¡œ ëŸ¬ìŠ¤íŠ¸ëŠ” í•¨ìˆ˜ ì‹œê·¸ë‹ˆì²˜ ë’¤ì˜ where ì ˆ ë‚´ë¶€ì— íŠ¸ë ˆì´íŠ¸ ë°”ìš´ë“œë¥¼ ì§€ì •í•˜ëŠ” ëŒ€ì²´ ë¬¸ë²•ì„ ì œê³µí•©ë‹ˆë‹¤. ë”°ë¼ì„œ ì´ë ‡ê²Œ ì“°ëŠ” ëŒ€ì‹ :

fn some_function<T: Display + Clone, U: Clone + Debug>(t: &T, u: &U) -> i32 {

ë‹¤ìŒê³¼ ê°™ì´ where ì ˆì„ ì‚¬ìš©í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤:

fn some_function<T, U>(t: &T, u: &U) -> i32
where
    T: Display + Clone,
    U: Clone + Debug,
{
    unimplemented!()
}

This functionâ€™s signature is less cluttered: The function name, parameter list, and return type are close together, similar to a function without lots of trait bounds.

íŠ¸ë ˆì´íŠ¸ë¥¼ êµ¬í˜„í•˜ëŠ” íƒ€ì… ë°˜í™˜í•˜ê¸°

ì—¬ê¸°ì„œ ë³´ì—¬ì§€ëŠ” ê²ƒì²˜ëŸ¼, íŠ¸ë ˆì´íŠ¸ë¥¼ êµ¬í˜„í•˜ëŠ” ì–´ë–¤ íƒ€ì…ì˜ ê°’ì„ ë°˜í™˜í•˜ê¸° ìœ„í•´ ë°˜í™˜ ìœ„ì¹˜ì— impl Trait ë¬¸ë²•ì„ ì‚¬ìš©í•  ìˆ˜ë„ ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤:

pub trait Summary {
    fn summarize(&self) -> String;
}

pub struct NewsArticle {
    pub headline: String,
    pub location: String,
    pub author: String,
    pub content: String,
}

impl Summary for NewsArticle {
    fn summarize(&self) -> String {
        format!("{}, {} ì‘ì„± ({})", self.headline, self.author, self.location)
    }
}

pub struct SocialPost {
    pub username: String,
    pub content: String,
    pub reply: bool,
    pub repost: bool,
}

impl Summary for SocialPost {
    fn summarize(&self) -> String {
        format!("{}: {}", self.username, self.content)
    }
}

fn returns_summarizable() -> impl Summary {
    SocialPost {
        username: String::from("horse_ebooks"),
        content: String::from(
            "ë¬¼ë¡ , ì´ë¯¸ ì•Œê³  ê³„ì‹œê² ì§€ë§Œ, ì‚¬ëŒë“¤",
        ),
        reply: false,
        repost: false,
    }
}

By using impl Summary for the return type, we specify that the returns_summarizable function returns some type that implements the Summary trait without naming the concrete type. In this case, returns_summarizable returns a SocialPost, but the code calling this function doesnâ€™t need to know that.

êµ¬í˜„í•˜ëŠ” íŠ¸ë ˆì´íŠ¸ë¡œë§Œ ë°˜í™˜ íƒ€ì…ì„ ì§€ì •í•˜ëŠ” ê¸°ëŠ¥ì€ 13ì¥ì—ì„œ ë‹¤ë£¨ëŠ” í´ë¡œì €ì™€ ë°˜ë³µìì˜ ë¬¸ë§¥ì—ì„œ íŠ¹íˆ ìœ ìš©í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤. í´ë¡œì €ì™€ ë°˜ë³µìëŠ” ì»´íŒŒì¼ëŸ¬ë§Œ ì•„ëŠ” íƒ€ì…ì´ë‚˜ ì§€ì •í•˜ê¸° ë§¤ìš° ê¸´ íƒ€ì…ì„ ìƒì„±í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤. impl Trait ë¬¸ë²•ì€ ë§¤ìš° ê¸´ íƒ€ì…ì„ ì‘ì„±í•  í•„ìš” ì—†ì´ í•¨ìˆ˜ê°€ Iterator íŠ¸ë ˆì´íŠ¸ë¥¼ êµ¬í˜„í•˜ëŠ” ì–´ë–¤ íƒ€ì…ì„ ë°˜í™˜í•œë‹¤ê³  ê°„ê²°í•˜ê²Œ ì§€ì •í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆê²Œ í•´ì¤ë‹ˆë‹¤.

However, you can only use impl Trait if youâ€™re returning a single type. For example, this code that returns either a NewsArticle or a SocialPost with the return type specified as impl Summary wouldnâ€™t work:

pub trait Summary {
    fn summarize(&self) -> String;
}

pub struct NewsArticle {
    pub headline: String,
    pub location: String,
    pub author: String,
    pub content: String,
}

impl Summary for NewsArticle {
    fn summarize(&self) -> String {
        format!("{}, {} ì‘ì„± ({})", self.headline, self.author, self.location)
    }
}

pub struct SocialPost {
    pub username: String,
    pub content: String,
    pub reply: bool,
    pub repost: bool,
}

impl Summary for SocialPost {
    fn summarize(&self) -> String {
        format!("{}: {}", self.username, self.content)
    }
}

fn returns_summarizable(switch: bool) -> impl Summary {
    if switch {
        NewsArticle {
            headline: String::from(
                "í­ê·„ìŠ¤, ìŠ¤íƒ ë¦¬ ì»µ ì±”í”¼ì–¸ì‹­ ìš°ìŠ¹!",
            ),
            location: String::from("ë¯¸êµ­ íœì‹¤ë² ì´ë‹ˆì•„ì£¼ í”¼ì¸ ë²„ê·¸"),
            author: String::from("ì•„ì´ìŠ¤ë²„ê·¸"),
            content: String::from(
                "í”¼ì¸ ë²„ê·¸ í­ê·„ìŠ¤ê°€ ë‹¤ì‹œ í•œ ë²ˆ NHL ìµœê³ ì˜ \
                 í•˜í‚¤ íŒ€ì´ ë˜ì—ˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤.",
            ),
        }
    } else {
        SocialPost {
            username: String::from("horse_ebooks"),
            content: String::from(
                "ë¬¼ë¡ , ì´ë¯¸ ì•Œê³  ê³„ì‹œê² ì§€ë§Œ, ì‚¬ëŒë“¤",
            ),
            reply: false,
            repost: false,
        }
    }
}

Returning either a NewsArticle or a SocialPost isnâ€™t allowed due to restrictions around how the impl Trait syntax is implemented in the compiler. Weâ€™ll cover how to write a function with this behavior in the â€œUsing Trait Objects to Abstract over Shared Behaviorâ€ section of Chapter 18.

íŠ¸ë ˆì´íŠ¸ ë°”ìš´ë“œë¥¼ ì‚¬ìš©í•˜ì—¬ ë©”ì„œë“œë¥¼ ì¡°ê±´ë¶€ë¡œ êµ¬í˜„í•˜ê¸°

By using a trait bound with an impl block that uses generic type parameters, we can implement methods conditionally for types that implement the specified traits. For example, the type Pair<T> in Listing 10-15 always implements the new function to return a new instance of Pair<T> (recall from the â€œMethod Syntaxâ€ section of Chapter 5 that Self is a type alias for the type of the impl block, which in this case is Pair<T>). But in the next impl block, Pair<T> only implements the cmp_display method if its inner type T implements the PartialOrd trait that enables comparison and the Display trait that enables printing.

use std::fmt::Display;

struct Pair<T> {
    x: T,
    y: T,
}

impl<T> Pair<T> {
    fn new(x: T, y: T) -> Self {
        Self { x, y }
    }
}

impl<T: Display + PartialOrd> Pair<T> {
    fn cmp_display(&self) {
        if self.x >= self.y {
            println!("ê°€ì¥ í° ë©¤ë²„ëŠ” x = {}", self.x);
        } else {
            println!("ê°€ì¥ í° ë©¤ë²„ëŠ” y = {}", self.y);
        }
    }
}

ìš°ë¦¬ëŠ” ë˜í•œ ë‹¤ë¥¸ íŠ¸ë ˆì´íŠ¸ë¥¼ êµ¬í˜„í•˜ëŠ” ëª¨ë“  íƒ€ì…ì— ëŒ€í•´ íŠ¸ë ˆì´íŠ¸ë¥¼ ì¡°ê±´ë¶€ë¡œ êµ¬í˜„í•  ìˆ˜ ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤. íŠ¸ë ˆì´íŠ¸ ë°”ìš´ë“œë¥¼ ë§Œì¡±í•˜ëŠ” ëª¨ë“  íƒ€ì…ì— ëŒ€í•œ íŠ¸ë ˆì´íŠ¸ êµ¬í˜„ì„ _í¬ê´„ì  êµ¬í˜„(blanket implementations)_ì´ë¼ê³  í•˜ë©°, ëŸ¬ìŠ¤íŠ¸ í‘œì¤€ ë¼ì´ë¸ŒëŸ¬ë¦¬ì—ì„œ ê´‘ë²”ìœ„í•˜ê²Œ ì‚¬ìš©ë©ë‹ˆë‹¤. ì˜ˆë¥¼ ë“¤ì–´, í‘œì¤€ ë¼ì´ë¸ŒëŸ¬ë¦¬ëŠ” Display íŠ¸ë ˆì´íŠ¸ë¥¼ êµ¬í˜„í•˜ëŠ” ëª¨ë“  íƒ€ì…ì— ëŒ€í•´ ToString íŠ¸ë ˆì´íŠ¸ë¥¼ êµ¬í˜„í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤. í‘œì¤€ ë¼ì´ë¸ŒëŸ¬ë¦¬ì˜ impl ë¸”ë¡ì€ ì´ ì½”ë“œì™€ ìœ ì‚¬í•´ ë³´ì…ë‹ˆë‹¤:

impl<T: Display> ToString for T {
    // --ìƒëµ--
}

í‘œì¤€ ë¼ì´ë¸ŒëŸ¬ë¦¬ì— ì´ëŸ¬í•œ í¬ê´„ì  êµ¬í˜„ì´ ìˆê¸° ë•Œë¬¸ì—, Display íŠ¸ë ˆì´íŠ¸ë¥¼ êµ¬í˜„í•˜ëŠ” ëª¨ë“  íƒ€ì…ì—ì„œ ToString íŠ¸ë ˆì´íŠ¸ì— ì •ì˜ëœ to_string ë©”ì„œë“œë¥¼ í˜¸ì¶œí•  ìˆ˜ ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤. ì˜ˆë¥¼ ë“¤ì–´, ì •ìˆ˜ëŠ” Displayë¥¼ êµ¬í˜„í•˜ë¯€ë¡œ ë‹¤ìŒê³¼ ê°™ì´ ì •ìˆ˜ë¥¼ í•´ë‹¹ String ê°’ìœ¼ë¡œ ë°”ê¿€ ìˆ˜ ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤:

#![allow(unused)]
fn main() {
let s = 3.to_string();
}

í¬ê´„ì  êµ¬í˜„ì€ íŠ¸ë ˆì´íŠ¸ ë¬¸ì„œì˜ â€œImplementorsâ€ ì„¹ì…˜ì— ë‚˜íƒ€ë‚©ë‹ˆë‹¤.

Traits and trait bounds let us write code that uses generic type parameters to reduce duplication but also specify to the compiler that we want the generic type to have particular behavior. The compiler can then use the trait bound information to check that all the concrete types used with our code provide the correct behavior. In dynamically typed languages, we would get an error at runtime if we called a method on a type that didnâ€™t define the method. But Rust moves these errors to compile time so that weâ€™re forced to fix the problems before our code is even able to run. Additionally, we donâ€™t have to write code that checks for behavior at runtime, because weâ€™ve already checked at compile time. Doing so improves performance without having to give up the flexibility of generics.

ë¼ì´í”„íƒ€ì„ìœ¼ë¡œ ì°¸ì¡° ìœ íš¨ì„± ê²€ì¦í•˜ê¸°

ë¼ì´í”„íƒ€ì„ì€ ìš°ë¦¬ê°€ ì´ë¯¸ ì‚¬ìš©í•˜ê³  ìˆë˜ ë˜ ë‹¤ë¥¸ ì¢…ë¥˜ì˜ ì œë„¤ë¦­ì…ë‹ˆë‹¤. íƒ€ì…ì´ ìš°ë¦¬ê°€ ì›í•˜ëŠ” ë™ì‘ì„ ê°–ë„ë¡ ë³´ì¥í•˜ëŠ” ëŒ€ì‹ , ë¼ì´í”„íƒ€ì„ì€ ì°¸ì¡°ê°€ í•„ìš”í•œ ë§Œí¼ ì˜¤ë«ë™ì•ˆ ìœ íš¨í•˜ë„ë¡ ë³´ì¥í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤.

One detail we didnâ€™t discuss in the â€œReferences and Borrowingâ€ section in Chapter 4 is that every reference in Rust has a lifetime, which is the scope for which that reference is valid. Most of the time, lifetimes are implicit and inferred, just like most of the time, types are inferred. We are only required to annotate types when multiple types are possible. In a similar way, we must annotate lifetimes when the lifetimes of references could be related in a few different ways. Rust requires us to annotate the relationships using generic lifetime parameters to ensure that the actual references used at runtime will definitely be valid.

Annotating lifetimes is not even a concept most other programming languages have, so this is going to feel unfamiliar. Although we wonâ€™t cover lifetimes in their entirety in this chapter, weâ€™ll discuss common ways you might encounter lifetime syntax so that you can get comfortable with the concept.

ëŒ•ê¸€ë§ ì°¸ì¡°

The main aim of lifetimes is to prevent dangling references, which, if they were allowed to exist, would cause a program to reference data other than the data itâ€™s intended to reference. Consider the program in Listing 10-16, which has an outer scope and an inner scope.

fn main() {
    let r;

    {
        let x = 5;
        r = &x;
    }

    println!("r: {r}");
}

Note: The examples in Listings 10-16, 10-17, and 10-23 declare variables without giving them an initial value, so the variable name exists in the outer scope. At first glance, this might appear to be in conflict with Rust having no null values. However, if we try to use a variable before giving it a value, weâ€™ll get a compile-time error, which shows that indeed Rust does not allow null values.

The outer scope declares a variable named r with no initial value, and the inner scope declares a variable named x with the initial value of 5. Inside the inner scope, we attempt to set the value of r as a reference to x. Then, the inner scope ends, and we attempt to print the value in r. This code wonâ€™t compile, because the value that r is referring to has gone out of scope before we try to use it. Here is the error message:

$ cargo run
   Compiling chapter10 v0.1.0 (file:///projects/chapter10)
error[E0597]: `x` does not live long enough
 --> src/main.rs:6:13
  |
5 |         let x = 5;
  |             - binding `x` declared here
6 |         r = &x;
  |             ^^ borrowed value does not live long enough
7 |     }
  |     - `x` dropped here while still borrowed
8 |
9 |     println!("r: {r}");
  |                   - borrow later used here

For more information about this error, try `rustc --explain E0597`.
error: could not compile `chapter10` (bin "chapter10") due to 1 previous error

The error message says that the variable x â€œdoes not live long enough.â€ The reason is that x will be out of scope when the inner scope ends on line 7. But r is still valid for the outer scope; because its scope is larger, we say that it â€œlives longer.â€ If Rust allowed this code to work, r would be referencing memory that was deallocated when x went out of scope, and anything we tried to do with r wouldnâ€™t work correctly. So, how does Rust determine that this code is invalid? It uses a borrow checker.

ë¹Œë ¤ì£¼ê¸° ê²€ì‚¬ê¸°

ëŸ¬ìŠ¤íŠ¸ ì»´íŒŒì¼ëŸ¬ëŠ” ëª¨ë“  ëŒ€ì—¬ê°€ ìœ íš¨í•œì§€ ê²°ì •í•˜ê¸° ìœ„í•´ ìŠ¤ì½”í”„ë¥¼ ë¹„êµí•˜ëŠ” _ë¹Œë ¤ì£¼ê¸° ê²€ì‚¬ê¸°(borrow checker)_ë¥¼ ê°€ì§€ê³  ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤. ëª©ë¡ 10-17ì€ ëª©ë¡ 10-16ê³¼ ë™ì¼í•œ ì½”ë“œì— ë³€ìˆ˜ì˜ ë¼ì´í”„íƒ€ì„ì„ ë³´ì—¬ì£¼ëŠ” ì£¼ì„ì„ ì¶”ê°€í•œ ê²ƒì…ë‹ˆë‹¤.

fn main() {
